PT J
AN ZOOR14705042322
DT Article
TI Composition and guilds of spiders (Arachnida: Araneae) in the trees
   canopies of an urban forest fragment, Salvador, Bahia, Brazil.
FT Composicao e guildas de aranhas (Arachnida: Areneae) em copas de um
   fragmento florestal urbano, Salvador, Bahia, Brasil.
AU Uzel Sena, Daniela
   Lima Peres, Marcelo Cesar
   Sousa Domingos, Bruno
   Fontoura, Talita
SO Revista Biociencias (Taubate)
VL 16
IS 1
PS 24-33
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present study aimed to assess the spiders' behavioral guilds and
   communities' composition, on trees canopies in an Atlantic Forest
   fragment edge. The samples were placed in the PituaYu Metropolitan Park
   (Salvador, Bahia), during the months of January and February, and April
   and May of 2008, totaling 72 sampling days. We captured the spiders by
   aerial capture traps, a new proposed method. Fifteen canopies were
   sampled and we identified nine species. A hundred and two spiders were
   collected and 21 species/morph species (SD = [plus or minus]2.52),
   distributed in 12 families and five guilds. The Jackknife 1 richness
   index estimated 32 species of spiders in the fragment edge. The genus
   Clubiona was the first register to the Park and the morph species
   Castianeira sp.1 (4.9%), Clubiona sp.1 (3.9%), Gypogyna sp.1 (2.9%),
   Lyssomanes sp.1 (2.9%) and Salticidae sp.1 (2.9%) were more abundant.
   The hunter guilds (78.4%) predominated the guilds (21.6%), and the
   Nocturnal Air Runners (CAN) represented 76.5% of all collected
   individuals.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Forestry
SN 1415-7411
BD Ecology; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Araneae [Community structure /  / ] [Forest and woodland / Forest canopy
   habitat / ] [Brazil / Bahia, Pituacu Metropolitan Park / ]. 
   Clubiona [Brazil / Bahia, Pituacu Metropolitan Park / New record]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Araneae (Arachnida). 
   Clubiona (Araneae): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705042322
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Harpalus Latreille, 1802 (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae) from China and faunistic notes on a species previously
   described.
AU Kataev, Boris M. (harpal@zin.ru) 
   Wrase, David W.
SO Vernate
VL 29
PS 157-160
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Harpalus hiekei sp. n. (type loc.: China, W Hubei, Guanmenshan, ca 1500
   m, 31[degree]45[minute]N 110[degree]40[minute]E) is described and
   compared with H. puetzi Kataev & Wrase, 1997. Illustrations of the
   median lobe of the male genitalia of both species and of left
   metepisternum, and left hemisternite with stylomeres of female genitalia
   of H. hiekei sp. n. are presented. Additionally some faunistic data on
   the occurrence of H. puetzi are given.
C1 Kataev, Boris M.; Zoological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences,
   Universitetskaya nab. 1, 199034 St. Petersburg, Russia, Russia.
EM harpal@zin.ru
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Harpalus (Harpalus) hiekei [Hubei /  / New species] [Sichuan /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Harpalus (Harpalus) hiekei (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Hubei, P. 158].

DT Article
TI [A further contribution on the genus Themus Motschulsky, 1858
   (Coleoptera: Cantharidae).]
FT Ein weiterer Beitrag zur Kenntnis der Gattung Themus Motschulsky, 1858
   (Coleoptera: Cantharidae).
AU Kopetz, Andreas (andreas.kopetz@jetzweb.de) 
SO Vernate
VL 29
PS 165-188
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB New species are described and illustrated: Themus (s.str.) murzini sp.
   nov. (China: Yunnan), Themus (s.str.) geiseri sp. nov. (Indien:
   Arunachal Pradesh), Themus (s.str.) minimus sp. nov. (Indien: Assam),
   Themus (s.str.) maoershanensis sp. nov. (China: Guangxi), Themus
   (s.str.) svihlai sp. nov. (Laos), Themus (Haplothemus) brancuccii sp.
   nov. (China: Sichuan), Themus (Haplothemus) tibetanus sp. nov. (China:
   Tibet), Themus (Haplothemus) constantini sp. nov. (China: Yunnan),
   Themus (Haplothemus) lapidarius sp. nov. (China: Tibet), Themus
   (Haplothemus) weiperti sp. nov. (Nepal), Themus (Haplothemus) latifrons
   sp. nov. (China: Yunnan), Themus (Haplothemus) flavolimbatus sp. nov.
   (Pakistan). Themus (s.str.) kambaiticomimus Wittmer, 1997 syn. nov. is
   synonymised with T. (s.str.) kambaiticus Wittmer, 1983. Supplementary
   description of the male of Themus (s.str.) mahunkai Wittmer, 1993 and
   additional illustrations or data for 9 already known species are given.
C1 Kopetz, Andreas; Dorfplatz 12, D-99198 Kerspleben, Germany, Germany.
EM andreas.kopetz@jetzweb.de
SC Zoology

DT Article
TI New and interesting Chrysomelidae (Insecta: Coleoptera) from the
   collection of the Naturkundemuseum Erfurt.
AU Medvedev, Lev N. (lev.medvedev@sevin.ru) 
SO Vernate
VL 29
PS 195-199
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The two species Aetheomorpha weigeli n. sp. (China, Yunnan) and Tibuboea
   namibica n.sp. (Namibia) are described as new for science. 15 species
   are firstly recorded for China and 2 species for Vietnam.
C1 Medvedev, Lev N.; Severtzov Institute of Ecology and Evolution, Leninsky
   prospect 33, Moscow 119071, Russia, Russia.
EM lev.medvedev@sevin.ru
SC Zoology

TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Chrysomelidae
OR Chrysomelidae (Chrysomeloidea): [New record]. 
   Aetheomorpha weigeli (Chrysomelidae): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 195].

PT J
AN ZOOR14705034878
DT Article
TI Description of a new microhylid frog species of the genus Xenorhina
   (Amphibia: Anura: Microhylidae) from the Fakfak Mountains, far western
   New Guinea.
AU Guenther, Rainer
SO Vertebrate Zoology
VL 60
IS 3
PS 217-224
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Based on morphological, bioacoustic, and molecular traits, a new species
   in the microhylid genus Xenorhina is described. It was recently
   discovered in the Fakfak Mountains, northwestern corner of the Bomberai
   Peninsula, Papua Province, Indonesia. This new species has no
   vomero-palatine spikes. According to molecular traits of the 12S and 16S
   rRNA genes, the new taxon is most closely related to a syntopic
   Xenorhina cf. oxycephala. It belongs to the smallest species in its
   genus and to those with the longest hind legs. Its advertisement call
   consists of a series of melodious notes lasting 5-6 seconds; mean note
   length 77 milliseconds, mean internote interval length 438 ms, and mean
   repetition rate 2.1 notes per second. The new species is fossorial and
   it occurs in primary and secondary rain forest at an elevation of from
   400 m to 900 m a.s.l.
C1 Guenther, Rainer; Museum Nat Kunde, Invalidenstr 43, D-10115 Berlin,
   Germany, Germany.
SC Zoology
SN 1864-5755
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Xenorhina arndti [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura,
   Microhylidae
OR Xenorhina arndti (Microhylidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 218]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705034878
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14705042303
DT Article
TI Trench treasures: the genus Princaxelia (Pardaliscidae, Amphipoda).
AU Lorz, A.N.
SO Zoologica Baetica
VL 21
PS 65-84
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The hadal amphipod fauna remains largely unknown. Recent investigations
   of the Japan and Izu-Ogasawara Trench with baited traps collected the
   largest specimens known so far of the genus Princaxelia (Pardaliscidae)
   at 7703 and 9316 meters. These belong to a new species which is here
   described in detail. A brief synopsis of the genus, a key to the species
   as well as a table with special morphological characters of all known
   Princaxelia is provided. The morphological adaptations for life in the
   hadal zone are briefly discussed.
C1 Lorz, A.N.; NIWA, National Institute of Water & Atomospheric Research,
   301 Evans Bay Parade, Wellington 6021, New Zealand, New Zealand.
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 1130-4251
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; General
   morphology; Evolution; Habitat; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Princaxelia [General morphology / Morphological adaptation / ]
   [Evolutionary adaptation /  / ] [Marine habitat / Hadal trench / ]. 
   Princaxelia jamiesoni [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Peracarida, Amphipoda

   subordinate taxa, P. 81; Key to species, P. 83]. 
   Princaxelia jamiesoni (Amphipoda): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 67].

DT Article
TI New data on the genus Jassa Leach (Amphipoda, Ischyroceridae).
AU Krapp, T. (traudl.krapp@uni-bonn.de) 
   Grasso, R.
   Ruffo, S.
SO Zoologica Baetica
VL 21
PS 85-100
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two small ischyrocerid amphipods were found in quite unusual habitats:
   one in thermal water of Sardinia, the other in a Sicilian cave 175 m
   above sea level. As the first is represented by only a single immature
   specimen, it is illustrated and described, without receiving a name; the
   second one could be fully described as a new species Jassa trinacriae.
C1 Krapp, T.; Zoologisches Forschungsmuseum A. Koenig, Adenauerallee 160,
   D-53113 Bonn, Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI Review of Australian species of Megastigmus (Hymenoptera: Torymidae)
   associated with Eucalyptus, with description of new species.
AU Doganlar, Mikdat (doganlar@mku.edu.tr) 
   Hassan, Errol
SO Australian Journal of Basic and Applied Sciences
VL 4
IS 10
PS 5059-5120
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The species of Megastigmus Dalman 1820 (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea:
   Torymidae), related with Eucalyptus species (Myrtaceae) from Australia
   were reviewed. A total of 33 species of Megastigmus were studied, with
   nine species described as new: chrisburwelli, erolhasani, judikingae,
   lawsoni, leptocybus, rieki, thailandiensis, thitipornae, zvimendeli.
   Three new synonymies are created: adelaidensis Girault syn.new =
   maculatipennis Girault, ater Girault syn.new = tasmaniensis Girault,
   trisulcus Girault syn.new = voltairei (Girault). All species were
   described in detail, with photographs of their diagnostic characters and
   available biological data provided. Some new diagnostic characters of
   the genus were found and added to the generic diagnosis of earlier
   authors. An identification key is provided for the treated Megastigmus
   species. Species of Megastigmus were recorded as parasitoids of the gall
   inducer insects or as a gall inducer in several parts of plants

DT Article
TI CLASSIFICATION, NATURAL HISTORY, AND EVOLUTION OF THE EPIPHLOEINAE
   (COLEOPTERA: CLERIDAE). PART VIII. THE GENERA ACANTHOCOLLUM OPITZ,
   STEGNOCLAVA OPITZ, AND ICHNEA LAPORTE.
AU Opitz, Weston (opitz@kwu.edu) 
SO Coleopterists Society Monographs Patricia Vaurie Series
VL 9
PS 1-65
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The checkered beetle genera Acanthocollum Opitz and Stegnoclava Opitz
   are redescribed and the genus Ichnea Laporte is revised for the first
   time. The monotypic genus Acanthocollum contains A. melanurum (Klug).
   Stegnoclava includes one previously described species, S. fumigata
   (Gorham), and two species describe herein, S. velatis Opitz, new
   species, and S. zorropsis Opitz, new species. Ichnea is comprised of 14
   previously described species and five new species. The previously
   described species are I. aequinoctialis Spinola, L aterrima (Klug), I.
   digna Wolcott, I. dimidiatiponnis Spinola, I. divisa (Chevrolat), L
   frenata (Erichson), L incerta Gorham, I. lycoides Laporte, marginella
   (Klug), I. mimica Gorham, I opaca (Klug), I. plumbea Gorham, I. praeusta
   (Klug), and L procera Schenkling. The species of Ichnea described herein
   are L acanthomelina Opitz, new species, I. atra Opitz, new species, L
   callanga Opitz, new species, I. gregata Opitz, new species, and I.
   gremia Opitz, new species. Seventeen new synonymies are designated: I.
   aequinoctialis (= I. funesta Gorham, I. histrica Gorham, L spinolai
   Corporaal); I. aterrima(= I. mexicana Thomson, L religiosa Chevrolat, I.
   vitticollis Kuwert, I. kuwerti Lohde, I. elongata Knoll); I. frenata (=
   L clLsfuncta Gorham, I. panamensis Gorham, I. subfasciata Gorham, I.
   mitella Gorham, I. striaticollis Kuwert, I. confluens Kuwert); I.
   marginella (Klug) (= Enoplium laterale Klug, Hylecoetus cylindricus
   Germar); I. plumbea Gorham (= I. helvolicollis Corporaal). The species
   of Acanthocollum characterized by having a ridge of golden yellow setae
   on the upper sides of the pronotum. Species of Stegnoclava have the
   antennal funicle extensively compacted, and in species of Ichnea the
   distal margin of the pygidium shows a distinct triangular, depigmented
   mark. Like other epiphloeines, species of Acanthocollum, Stegnoclava,
   and Ichnea are thought to be predators of lignicolous insects and highly
   involved in Batesian polymorphism. TWO major lines of evolution arc
   apparent within Ichnea, one having evolved toward a lycid type of body
   form, whereas the other progressed towards a lampyroid configuration.
   Twenty-one characters were evaluated phylogenetically and analyzed with
   WINCLADA, in coordination with NONA, to generate a nearly completely
   resolved species-group level phylogeny. It is postulated that the
   progenitor of the three genera evolved in South America, with subsequent
   ancestral stocks extending into Central America following the closure of
   the Panamanian portal.
C1 Opitz, Weston; Kansas Wesleyan Univ, Dept Biol, 100 E Claflin Ave,
   Salina, KS, USA, USA.
EM opitz@kwu.edu
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1934-0451
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis;
   Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation; Publications;
   Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Neotropical region; Central
   America; South America

SO Genus (Wroclaw)

PS 495-499
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Neuraphes (Pararaphes) hengduanus n. sp. from China (Yunnan) is
   described, and its diagnostic characters arc discussed and illustrated.
   The new species belongs to the East Palearctic group of Neuraphes
   characterized by the distinctly bicolorous body (the head and pronotum
   much darker than the elytra).

   established: A. semiermis (LESNE) proved taxonomically identical to A.
   cornifrons (LESNE). For A. semiermis neotype has been designated,
   currently housed in the collection of Museum d'Histoire Naturelle in

DT Article
TI Seed beetles associated with Desmodieae in Vietnam (Coleoptera:
   Chrysomelidae: Bruchinae).
AU Delobel, Alex (delobel.alex@aliceadsl.fr) 
SO Genus (Wroclaw)
VL 21
IS 4
PS 513-533
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Six new species of Bruchinae are reported from Vietnam as feeding in
   seeds of members of leguminous tribe Desmodieae (Fabaceae-Faboideae).
   These species are described in genus Bruchidius: B. christiae, B.
   dendrolobii, B. nebulatus, B. phuanensis, B. urariae, and B.
   vinhanensis. Original biological data arc given for six additional
   species: B. anderssoni DECELLE, B. brincki DECELLE, B. desmodei ARORA,
   B. meibomiaca ARORA, B. mendosus (GYLL.), B. mussooriensis ARORA. A key
   to known Vietnamese species is provided.

TI A New Thyropygine Milliped from Sabah (Spirostreptida: Harpagophoridae).
AU Hoffman, Richard L. (richard.hoffman@vmnh.virginia.gvo) 
SO International Journal of Myriapodology
VL 3
IS 2
PS 181-188
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Spissustreptus strigilectus is described as a new species from a male
   specimen collected in the Kabili-Sepilok Forest Reserve, northern Sabah.
   Although showing some a nity with the sympatric S. hosei (Pocock, 1892),
   strigilectus differs from all known members of the genus by the presence
   of an elongated, medially directed, process on the arculus region of the
   gonopod. The two Phillippine species named Spirostreptus moseleyi
   Pocock, 1893, and Spirosteptus foveolatus Karsch, 1881, are tentatively
   referred to this genus, with historical commentary, new combination for
   both names.
C1 Hoffman, Richard L.; Virginia Museum of Natural History, Martinsville,
   Virginia 24112, USA, USA.
EM richard.hoffman@vmnh.virginia.gvo

   position; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   Spissustreptus, p. 186]. 
   Spirostreptus moseleyi - Pocock 1893 (Diplopoda): [Referred to,
   Spissustreptus, p. 187].

PT J
AN ZOOR14704031359
DT Article
TI NON-MINERALISED DISCOIDAL FOSSILS FROM THE ORDOVICIAN BARDAHESSIAGH
   FORMATION, CO. TYRONE, IRELAND.
AU MacGabhann, Breandan Anraoi (b.macgabhann1@nuigalway.ie) 
   Murray, John
SO Irish Journal of Earth Sciences
VL 28
PS 1-12
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Four non-mineralised fossils from the Ordovician Bardahessiagh
   Formation, near Pomeroy, Co. Tyrone, have been examined for the first
   time following their recovery from a temporary trench dug in 1992, and
   are here described as Seputus pomeroii gen. et sp. nov. These are
   discoidal impressions with up to 120 radial ridges extending from a
   central ring to a sharply defined margin, and they are tentatively
   interpreted as rotadiscid eldonids. The fossils are preserved as moulds
   and casts in a medium-grained quartzose sandstone bed, which is densely
   packed with corals, trilobites, brachiopods and delicately preserved
   echinoderms, probably representing an event bed on an outer shelf or
   upper slope setting. The non-mineralised fossils are likely to represent
   a paraautochthonous assemblage of benthic organisms, preserved by early
   diagenic mineralisation in anaerobic conditions produced by the decay of
   organic matter entrained within the bed, a mode of preservation broadly
   similar to that of non-mineralised fossils from the Ediacaran System.
   The preserved discs are believed to represent a tough exterior more
   resistant to decay than the (unknown) remainder of the organism.
C1 MacGabhann, Breandan Anraoi; Earth and Ocean Sciences, National
   University of Ireland, Galway, University Road, Galway, Republic of
   Ireland, Republic of Ireland.
EM b.macgabhann1@nuigalway.ie
OI MacGabhann, Breandan/0000-0002-5422-4638
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0790-1763
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Seputus [Ordovician /  / New genus]. 
   Seputus pomeroii [Northern Ireland /  / new species] [Ordovician /  / ].
   
ST Animalia
OR Seputus (Animalia): [Gen nov, Of family Rotadiscidae?, Type species
   Seputus pomeroii, p. 3, Ordovician; Fossil]. 
   Seputus pomeroii (Animalia): [Sp nov, Northern Ireland, Ordovician, P.
   3; Fossil].

DT Article
TI RETEPORA UNDATA M'COY, 1844, TYPE SPECIES OF PHYLLOPORELLA FREDERIKS,
   1916, A JUNIOR SYNONYM OF CHAINODICTYON FOERSTE, 1887: A PHYLLOPORINID
   BRYOZOAN FROM THE MISSISSIPPIAN OF IRELAND REDESCRIBED.
AU Wyse Jackson, Patrick N. (wysjcknp@tcd.ie) 
   McKinney, Frank K.
   Ernst, Andrej
SO Irish Journal of Earth Sciences
VL 28
PS 53-60
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Retepora undata M'Coy, 1844, from the Mississippian of Ireland is shown
   to be a phylloporinid bryozoan of the genus Chainodictyon Foerste, 1887.
   It forms reticulated zoaria of anastomosing branches with characteristic
   droplet-shaped fenestrules. The status of the genus Phylloporella
   Frederiks, 1916, which was originally named with two type species is
   here formalised through designation of Retepora undata M'Coy, 1844, as
   the type species. Phylloporella Frederiks, 1916, is a junior synonym of
   Chainodictyon, Foerste, 1887.
C1 Wyse Jackson, Patrick N.; Department of Geology, Trinity College, Dublin

PT J
AN ZOOR14704033486
DT Article
TI First record of Lecithochirium sp. (Digenea: Hemiuridae) in the marine
   fish Carangoides bajad from the Red Sea, coast of Yemen.
AU Al-Zubaidy, Ali B.
SO Journal of King Abdulaziz University Marine Sciences
VL 21
PS 85-94
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present study is the first investigation of digenetic trematode
   parasites in C. bajad, a commercially important teleost fish species of
   the Red Sea, Coast of Yemen from AL-Khatheib region, in the coast city
   of Hodeidah, during the period from January to December 2006. A total of
   112 C.bajad ( Local name: Bayad ) were examined, 16 specimens were found
   harboring Lecithochirium sp. (Lecithochirium: Hemiuridae). The
   prevalence and mean intensity of infection were 14.3 % and 2.9
   respectively. And the number of parasite per fish range 1-6. Prevalence
   and intensity of infection was positively correlated with host size
   (increasing with host size increasing). Host sex does not seem to affect
   prevalence of infection. The present work represents the first record
   for the presence of this parasite in C. bajad fish in Yemen's coastal
   Red Sea water.
C1 Al-Zubaidy, Ali B.; Department of Marine Biology & Fisheries, Faculty of
   Marine Science & Environment, Hodeidah University, Yemen, Yemen.
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1021-1802
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian Ocean
DE Carangoides bajad [Digenean parasites / Lecithochirium / New record;
   prevalence] [Red Sea / Yemen, Al-Khatheib region / ]. 
   Lecithochirium [Piscean hosts / Carangoides bajad / New record;
   prevalence] [Red Sea / Yemen, Al-Khatheib region / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Carangidae, Platyhelminthes, Trematoda, Digenea
OR Carangoides bajad (Carangidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Lecithochirium (Digenea): [Parasite; New record]. 
DI 10.4197/Mar.21-1.4

PT J
AN ZOOR14704033612
DT Article
TI A new species of Bolbelasmus Boucomont, 1911 (Insecta Coleoptera
   Geotrupidae) from Sicily (Italy).
AU Arnone, Marcello (marcel.arnone@gmail.it) 
   Massa, Bruno
SO Naturalista Siciliano
VL 34
IS 3-4
PS 401-414
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Authors have examined scrupolously all available sicilian specimens
   belonging to the genus Bolbelasmus, collected between 1893 and 2010,
   previously identified as B. gallicus and B. unicornis. They conclude
   that both species have to be excluded from the sicilian fauna and
   describe the new species B. romanorum, which is characterized by
   peculiar punctures on the clypeus, the head and the pronotum, and by the
   shape of the clypeus, the head and the aedeagus sclerites. They compare
   the new species with all the taxa currently known in theMediterranean.
   Further, they show oscillograms of both sexes of the new species, which,
   as other Bolbelasmus, stridulates vigorously; they also detect for the
   first time the pars stridens, consisting in a series of small bristles
   on the lower outer border of wings; the insect emits its sound moving
   actively the abdomen, the friction of the wing on the first abdominal
   tergite, particularly swollen, produces the stridulation.
C1 Arnone, Marcello; via F. Vivona 15, 90145 Palermo, Italy, Italy.
EM marcel.arnone@gmail.it
SC Zoology
SN 0394-0063
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Italy
DE Bolbelasmus romanorum [Sicily /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Scarabaeoidea,
   Geotrupidae
OR Bolbelasmus romanorum (Geotrupidae): [Sp nov, Sicily, P. 403]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704033612
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14704030944
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Abundance and species distribution peculiarities of oribatid mites
   (Acari: Oribatida) in regenerating forest soils.
AU Matuseviciute, Audrone (audrone@ekoi.lt) 
SO New and Rare for Lithuania Insect Species Records and Descriptions
VL 22
PS 37-42
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The abundance, diversity and community structure of soil mites (Acari:
   Oribatida) in regenerating forest soils were investigated. The study of
   oribatid mites in soil of a 16-year-old pinewood showed that their
   abundance was 29.7 thousand ind. m-2 on average. Seven species of
   orbatid mites were detected. Analysis of the dominant structure of
   oribatid mites revealed a distinct eudominance of one species, Oppiella
   nova, which constituted 55.3% of the whole community of oribatid mites.
   Tectocepheus velatus and Brachychthonius sp. remain the dominant
   species. The study of oribatid mites in soil of a 40-year-old pinewood
   showed that their abundance was 60.5 thousand ind. m-2 on average; 35
   species of orbatid mites were detected. Oppiella nova, constituting 44.0
   % of all oribatid mites, is an eudominant species in soil. Tectocepheus
   velatus, Suctobelba sp., Suctobelbella sp., Medioppia obsoleta, and
   Microppia minus are subdominant species. Five species of oribatid mites
   new for Lithuania were identified in the investigated localities.

PT J

DT Article
TI Two new nematode species of the subfamily Brittonematinae (Dorylaimida:
   Actinolaimidae).
AU Andrassy, Istvan
SO Opuscula Zoologica (Budapest)
VL 41
IS 2
PS 175-190
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of actinolaimoid nematodes of the subfamily
   Brittonematinae are described and illustrated. Actinca marisae sp. n.
   from Brazil is characterized by the long (on average 2.92 mm) and
   slender body, 30[long dash]32 distinct longitudinal ridges on cuticle,
   narrow head, slender odontostyle, onchial tips facing each other,
   cylindrus occupying somewhat less than one-half of pharynx, broad vulval
   lips, and by medum long tail. Afractinca eburnea sp. n. from Cote
   d'Ivoire can be distinguished by a relatively long body (on average 1.88
   mm), thin cuticle provided with 14 longitudinal ridges, cap-like offset
   labial ring, very slender odontostyle, long prerectum, vulva sunk in
   body contour, and by the elongate-conoid female tail. Main morphological
   structures of Actinca and Afractinca species are summarized. Some
   comments on further brittonematine species are added.
C1 Andrassy, Istvan; Department of Systematic Zoology and Ecology of the
   Eotvos Lorand University, Systematic Zoology Research Group of the
   Hungarian Academy of Sciences, Pazmany Peter setany 1/C, 1117 Budapest,
   Hungary, Hungary.
SC Zoology
SN 0237-5419
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Combination; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Neotropical region;
   Africa; South America
DE Actinca marisae [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Afractinca [Ivory Coast /  / Distribution]. 
   Afractinca eburnea [Ivory Coast /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Actinca - Andrassy 1964 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters, P. 180;
   Included taxa, Species list, p. 183]. 
   Actinca intermedia - Andrassy 1968 (Nematoda): [Referred to,
   Parastomachoglossa, p. 184]. 
   Actinca marisae (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 175]. 
   Actinolaimus papillatus - Schneider 1935 (Nematoda): [Taxonomic
   position, Generic placement, p. 187]. 
   Afractinca - Vinciguerra & Clausi 2000 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 180]. 
   Afractinca eburnea (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Ivory Coast, P. 179]. 
   Brittonema - Thorne 1967 (Nematoda): [Status, P. 184]. 
   Parastomachoglossa intermedia - (Andrassy 1968) (Nematoda): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Actinca, p. 184]. 
   Parastomachoglossa japonica - Tsalolikhin 1999 (Nematoda): [Taxonomic

DT Article
TI New and little known oribatid species from Kenya (Acari: Oribatida).
AU Mahunka, Sandor (mahunka@nhmus.hu) 
   Mahunka-Papp, Luise
SO Opuscula Zoologica (Budapest)
VL 41
IS 2
PS 207-213
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new (Megazetes lineatus and Hypozetes stellifer spp. nov.) and a
   little known oribatid species are described from different regions in
   Kenya. Scapheremaeus hungarorum Mahunka, 1986 described originally from
   Tanzania is reported first time from this country. The three species
   discussed belong to three different families of Oribatida: Microzetidae,
   Tegoribatidae and Cymbaeremaeidae, respectively. Some notes on the
   relationships of the new species and redescription of S. hungarorum are
   also given. With 10 figures.
C1 Mahunka, Sandor; Systematic Zoology Research Group of the Hungarian
   Academy of Sciences, and Department of Zoology, Hungarian Natural
   History Museum, H-1088 Budapest, Baross u. 13, Hungary, Hungary.
EM mahunka@nhmus.hu

SN 0237-5419

   Africa

   Scapheremaeus hungarorum [Kenya /  / New record]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Hypozetes stellifer (Acari): [Sp nov, Kenya, P. 211]. 
   Megazetes lineatus (Acari): [Sp nov, Kenya, P. 207]. 
   Scapheremaeus hungarorum (Acari): [New record].

TI Gastropods of rare families from the Tshegan Formation of Kazakhstan.
AU Amitrov, O.V. (amitrov@mail.ru) 
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 4
PS 24-29
PD Iyul-Avgust 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal. .
   Separate unpaginated plate.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eight gastropod species, rare in the Tshegan Formation, are considered.
   These species and six families, which include these species, were only
   mentioned in faunal lists of this formation (Amitrov, 1994, 2005). Two
   new species, Periaulax tsheganica sp. nov. (Trochidae) and Pusillina
   kazakhstanica sp. nov. (Rissoidae), are described. Other six species of
   the families Diastomatidae, Marginellidae, Melanellidae, and Mathildidae
   are figured and compared with related species; their distribution is
   discussed.

TI Some ostracodes from the Guryanovka Formation (Upper Ordovician) of
   northeastern Gorny Altai.
AU Melnikova, L.M. (lmelnik@paleo.ru) 
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 4
PS 38-46
PD Iyul-Avgust 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
   Separate unpaginated plates.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ostracodes from the Guryanovka Formation (Upper Ordovician, Sandbian and
   Katian stages) of Gorny Altai, Russia, are studied for the first time.
   Some localities with fossil ostracodes of this age are described
   briefly. Eleven new species of the genera Ballardina, Eurychilina,
   Laccochi/ina, Bolbina, Retiprimites, Pseudozygobolbina, Bullaeferum,
   Soanella, Egorovella, and Allertemysa are described and figured. The
   previously described species Leperditella aff. parvipunctata V. Ivanova,
   1959, Grammolomatella valdari V. Ivanova et Melnikova 1977, Longidorsa
   baltica Meidla, 1996, and Steusloffina cuneata (Steusloff, 1895) and
   ostracodes in open nomenclature, Bollia sp., Klimphores sp., Rectella
   sp., Longiscula sp., are only figured.

DT Article
TI A new subfamily of ichneumon wasps (Insecta: Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae)
   from the Upper Cretaceous of the Russian Far East.
AU Kopylov, D.S. (aeschna@yandex.ru) 
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 4
PS 59-69
PD Iyul-Avgust 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
   Unpaginated plates.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new subfamily of ichneumon wasps, Labenopimplinae subfam. nov.
   (Ichneumonidae), is described from the Cenomanian Ola Formation of the
   locality Obeshchayushchiy, Magadan Region, Russian Far East. The
   sub-family is highly diverse morphologically and combines characters of
   the Labeninae and Pimplinae. It includes 11 new species described in
   five new genera: Labenopimpla rasnitsyni gen. et sp. nov., L. kasparyani
   sp. nov, Armanopimpla zherikhini gen. et sp. nov, Ramulimonstrum
   intermedium gen. et sp. nov., Rugopimpla vulgaris gen. et sp. nov., R.
   fallax sp. nov., R. angusticella sp. nov., R. macra sp. nov., R. matrona
   sp. nov., Micropimpla lucida gen. et sp. nov., and M. obscura sp. nov.
   Also described is a new monotypic genus, Tryphopimpla xoridoptera gen.
   et sp. nov., which combines characters of the Tryphoninae, Pimplinae,
   and Xoridinae and cannot be currently placed into any of the known
   subfamilies. The population of fossil ichneumon wasps at this locality
   is distinctly dominated by females.
C1 Kopylov, D.S.; Paleontologicheskii institut im. A.A. Borisyaka RAN,
   Russia, Russia.
EM aeschna@yandex.ru

TI New and little known orthopteroid insects (Polyneoptera) from fossil
   resins: communication 3.
AU Gorokhov, A.V. (orthopt@zin.ru) 
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 4
PS 70-87
PD Iyul-Avgust 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB New taxa of Orthoptera Ensifera are described in the families
   Mogoplistidae: Protomogoplistes asquamosus gen. et sp. nov. (Upper
   Cretaceous) in the subfamily Protomogoplistinae subfam. nov and
   Archornebius balticus gen. et sp. nov. (Eocene), Pseudarachnocephalus
   gen. nov., P. dominicanus sp. nov., and P. latiusculus sp. nov. (all
   Miocene) in Mogoplistinae, and Gryllidae: Eopentacentrus borealis gen.
   etsp. nov. (Eocene), ?Grossoxipha feminea sp. nov. (Miocene), and
   Apentacentrus copalicus sp. nov in the subfamily Pentacentrinae,
   ?Cyrtoxipha electrina sp. nov. and ?Cyrtoxipha illegibilis sp. nov.
   (both Miocene) in Trigonidiinae, and Baltonemobiusfossilis gen. et sp.
   nov. (Eocene) in Nemobiinae. The Miocene genera Proanaxipha Vickery et
   Poinar and Grossoxipha 'Vickery et Poinar are transferred from the
   subfamily Trigonidiinae to Pentacentrinae. P. latoca Vickery et Poinar
   and Abanaxipha longispina Vickery et Poinar are redescribed; the male of
   the latter species is described for the first time.

PT J
AN ZOOR14704026975
DT Article
TI New beetle species of the formal genus Artematopodites (Coleoptera:
   Polyphaga), with remarks on the taxonomic position of the genera
   Ovivagina and Sinonitidulina.
AU Yan, E.V. (yan-e@mail.ru) 
   Zhang, Haichun
SO Paleontologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 4
PS 88-93
PD Iyul-Avgust 2010
PY 2010
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Paleontological Journal.
   Separate unpaginated plate.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new beetle species of the formal genus Artematopoides, i.e., A.
   maximus sp. nov., A. crispulus sp. nov., and A. lepidus sp. nov., from
   the Mongolian Shar-Teg locality are described. Early Jurassic Ovivagina
   propinqua Zhang, 1997, O. prolixa Zhang, 1997, and O. insculpta Zhang,
   1997 from the Junggar Basin (Xinjiang, China) and Middle Jurassic
   Sinonitidulina Tonga Hong, 1983 from the Zhouyingzi locality (Hebei,
   China) are transferred to Artematopoides, and the three species from
   Xinjiang are redescribed. Ovivagina immediata Zhang, 1997 is synonymized
   with O. insculpta Zhang, 1997. A new name, Artematopodites leskoviensis
   Yan, nom. nov, is proposed for A. longus Ponomarenko, 1990, which proved
   to be a junior secondary homonym of A. longa (Hong, 1983).
C1 Yan, E.V.; Paleontologicheskii institut im. A.A. Borisyaka RAN, Russia,
   Russia.
EM yan-e@mail.ru

SN 0031-031X

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

PT J
AN ZOOR14704030146
DT Article
TI Schaarschmidtia, a new subgenus of the genus Tarsonemus Canestrini &
   Fanzago, 1876 (Acari: Heterostigmatina: Tarsonemidae) - a systematic
   review of the mite taxon associated with subcortical coleopteran
   insects, with notes on its host affiliation, ecology and biogeography.
AU Magowski, Wojciech L. (magowski@amu.edu.pl) 
SO Polish Journal of Entomology
VL 79
SU (Supplement)
PS i-ii, 1-176
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new subgenus of mites of the genus Tarsonemus CANESTRINI & FANZAGO,
   1876 (family Tarsonemidae) is erected and described based on Tarsonemus
   ips LINDQUIST, 1969. Following species are new combinations under the
   new subgeneric name: Tarsonemus pyrrhidi SCHAARSCHMIDT, 1959,
   Tarsonemoides micrungulatus SCHAARSCHMIDT, 1959, Heterotarsonemus
   egregius LIVSHITZ, MITROFANOV & SHARONOV, 1982, Hemitarsonemus
   angolensis CARMONA, 1969, Tarsonemus naegelei SUSKI, 1967, T. ips
   LINDQUIST, 1969, T. kennedyi SMILEY & MOSER, 1974, (=T. pseudokennedyi
   OCHOA, 1991 n. syn.), T. spathulaphorus MAGOWSKI & KHAUSTOV, 1999
   (incertae sedis), T. wilkinsoni SMILEY & MOSER, 1974, T. fraxini
   MAGOWSKI & KHAUSTOV, 2006, T. bistridentati MAGOWSKI & KHAUSTOV, 2006
   and T. amygdali MAGOWSKI, DIDUSZKO & AHADIYAT, 2007. The type- and
   member-species are redescribed or rediagnosed, and illustrated.
   Descriptions of following new species are given: T. (S.) cochise, T.
   (S.) populi, T. (S.) acmocerae, T. (S.) balazyi and T (S.) mahunkai. A
   key for the determination of species is supplied. The systematic
   position, biology, ecology and phylogeny of the new subgeneric taxon are
   discussed. Species of the new subgenus are often associated with
   subcortical scolytid and cerambycid beetles, and geographically cover
   the temperate zone as well as some tropical regions.
C1 Magowski, Wojciech L.; Department of Animal Taxonomy and Ecology, A.
   Mickiewicz University, Umultowska 89, 61-614 Poznan, Poland, Poland.
EM magowski@amu.edu.pl
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0032-3780
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key; Documentation; Publications; Associations; Commensalism;
   Land zones; Afrotropical region; Nearctic region; Palaearctic region;
   Africa; Eurasia; Europe; North America; USA

AN ZOOR14704032831
DT Article
TI On Pseudocorynactis species and another related genus from the
   Indo-Pacific (Anthozoa: Corallimorphidae).
AU Ocana, O. (lebruni@telefonica.net) 
   de Hartog, J.C.
   Brito, A.
   Bos, A.R.
SO Revista de la Academia Canaria de Ciencias
VL 21
IS 3-4
PS 9-34
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Tentacles development is important for the Corallimorphidae in terms of
   speciation, being interesting to discuss about the presence of different
   evolutionary levels in tentacle anatomy. We studied three species of
   Corallimorpharia belonging two of them to Pseudocorynactis and one to
   the new genus Paracorynactis. The extendible capability of the tentacles
   is proposed to make difference among the above mentioned genera. The
   species Pseudocorynactis globulifera from the Red Sea is include in this
   genus for the first time, we also have described the new species
   Pseudocorynactis tuberculata from Indonesia and Maldives. The help
   control of Paracorynactis hoplites on the crown of thorns sea stars
   population is exposed.
C1 Ocana, O.; Departamento deo Oceanografia Biologica y Biodiversidad,
   Fundacion Museo del Mar, Muelle Canonero Dato s.n, 51001, Ceuta, Spain,
   Spain.
EM lebruni@telefonica.net
SC Zoology
SN 1130-4723
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Diagnosis;
   Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Marine zones; Pacific
   Ocean
DE Pseudocorynactis tuberculata [South Pacific / Indonesia / New species].

   to, Pseudocorynactis, p. 20]. 
   Corynactis hoplites - Haddon & Shackleton 1893 (Corallimorpharia):
   [Designated type species for new genus, Paracorynactis, p. 12]. 
   Paracorynactis (Corallimorpharia): [Gen nov, Of family Corallimorphidae,
   Type species Corynactis hoplites Haddon & Shackleton 1893, p. 12]. 
   Paracorynactis hoplites - (Haddon & Shackleton 1893) (Corallimorpharia):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Corynactis, p. 12].

   diagnosis, P. 20].

   (marine), P. 26].

TI [New data and new species of the family Marginellidae Fleming, 1828
   (Mollusca: Neogastropoda) in the Cuban archipielago.]

AB Description of a genus and 10 new species of the family Marginellidae, 8
   of Volvarina Hinds, 1844, and two of Prunum Hettmannsen, 1852, collected
   in different localities from Cuban archipelago, contributing with new

   authors.

DT Article
TI [Contribution on the study of the genus Doto Oken, 1815 (Mollusca:
   Nudibranchia) in Ceuta (Spain) with description of new species.]
FT Contribucion al estudio del genero Doto Oken, 1815 (Mollusca:
   Nudibranchia) en Ceuta (Espana) con la descripcion de nuevas especies.
AU Ortea, J.
   Moro, L.
   Ocana, O.
   Bacallado, J.J.
SO Revista de la Academia Canaria de Ciencias
VL 21
IS 3-4
PS 81-91
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB We have studied five species of the Doto Oken, 1815 genus, collected in
   Ceuta litoral (2 to 35 m depth). Two species, D. floridicola y D. furva,
   were known for the coast of Ceuta. Doto koenneckery is first time
   recorded in Ceuta, and the other two are new species: D. alidrisi, which
   presents big tubercles in the cerata forming a cross in their
   arrangement with the cerata, and D. caballa, with a robust body
   narrowing sharply towards the end, balloon shape cerata with a
   characteristic colour. We include colour images and drawings of all the
   species described in this paper.
C1 Ortea, J.; Departamento BOS, Universidad de Oviedo, 33075 Oviedo,
   Asturias, Spain, Spain.
SC Zoology
SN 1130-4723
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic
DE Doto [Mediterranean Sea / Ceuta / Distribution; new record;
   systematics]. 
   Doto alidrisi; Doto caballa [Mediterranean Sea /  / New species]. 
   Doto koenneckeri [Mediterranean Sea / Ceuta / New record]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Opisthobranchia, Nudibranchia
OR Doto - Oken 1815 (Nudibranchia): [New record]. 
   Doto alidrisi - Ortea, Moro & Ocana 2010 (Nudibranchia): [Sp nov,
   Mediterranean Sea, P. 84]. 
   Doto caballa - Ortea, Moro & Bacallado 2010 (Nudibranchia): [Sp nov,
   Mediterranean Sea, P. 86]. 
   Doto koenneckeri (Nudibranchia): [New record].

TI [A new family, genus and species of gastropod mollusc (Mollusca:
   Gastropoda) from the submarine caves of Cuba.]
FT Nueva familia, genero y especie de molusco Gasteropodo (Mollusca:
   Gastropoda) de las cuevas submarinas de Cuba.
AU Espinosa, J.
   Ortea, J.
SO Revista de la Academia Canaria de Ciencias
VL 21
IS 3-4
PS 93-98
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A bizarre gastropod species, Globocornus darwini, new species, is
   described from a shallow-water submarine cave in Cuba as a new family,
   genus and species, based on a empty shell and additional fragmented
   shells.

PT J
AN ZOOR14704032853
DT Article
TI [Three new species of Doto Oken, 1815 (Mollusca: Nudibranchia),
   collected in the Caribbean of Costa Rica and off the Galapagos islands.]
FT Tres nuevas especies de Doto Oken, 1815 (Mollusca: Nudibranchia),
   colectadas en el Caribe de Costa Rica y en las islas Galapagos.
AU Ortea, J.
SO Revista de la Academia Canaria de Ciencias
VL 21
IS 3-4
PS 109-115
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three new species of the genus Doto Oken, 1815, are described. Two of
   them were collected in Galapagos Islands during the course of a cruise
   managed by Museo de Ciencias Naturales de Tenerife, in April of 1990.
   The third one was discovered in February of 2002 in the Caribbean Sea
   from Costa Rica. All three are characterized for having unique
   anatomical characters when are compared with the known species of the
   genus. Their descriptions are made from the scarce material obtained
   from the samples collected during last 20 years, due to the difficulty
   of sampling in the areas where it live.
C1 Ortea, J.; Instituto de Oceanologia, Ave. 1ra e 184/186, Playa, La
   Habana, Cuba, Cuba.
SC Zoology
SN 1130-4723
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic; Pacific Ocean
DE Doto cristal [Caribbean Sea / Costa Rica / New species]. 
   Doto galapagoensis; Doto xangada [South Pacific / Galapagos Islands /
   New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Opisthobranchia, Nudibranchia
OR Doto cristal (Nudibranchia): [Sp nov, Costa Rica (marine), P. 110]. 
   Doto galapagoensis (Nudibranchia): [Sp nov, Galapagos Islands (marine),
   P. 113]. 
   Doto xangada (Nudibranchia): [Sp nov, Galapagos Islands (marine), P.
   111].

PT B
AN ZOOR14704033730
DT Book
TI Rhyzobius (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae) a revision of the world species.
AU Tomaszewska, Wioletta (wiolkat@miiz.waw.pl) 
BA Tomaszewska, Wioletta
SO Rhyzobius (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae) a revision of the world species.
   [Fauna Mundi Volume 2.]
PS 1-475
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The world species of Rhyzobius Stephens are reviewed and illustrated.
   The following new synonyms are proposed: Rhyzobius aurantii Blackburn,
   1892 (= Rhizobius vulgaris Weise, 1923), Rhyzobius breweri Crotch, 1874
   (= Rhizobius corticalis Lea, 1902), Rhyzobius evansii Mulsant, 1850
   (=Rhizobius confinis Lea, 1902), Rhyzobius nitidus Blackburn, 1889 (=
   Rhizobius plebeius Blackburn 1892), Rhyzobius satelles Blackburn, 1892
   (= Rhizobius kingensis Lea, 1908; = Rhizobius erythrogaster Lea, 1929; =
   Scymnus fagus Broun, 1880; = Rhyzobius nigrovatus Bielawski, 1973);
   Rhyzobius pulchellus (Montrouzier, 1861) (= Rhizobius submetallica
   Crotch 1874; = Rhizobius debilis Blackburn, 1889; = Rhizobius lindi
   Blackburn, 1889; = Rhizobius coeruleus Blackburn, 1892), Rhyzobius
   waterhousei (Mulsant, 1850) (= Rhizobius speratus Blackburn, 1889). The
   lectotypes are designated for: Rhizobius alphabeticus Lea, Rhizobius
   apicalis Blackburn, Rhizobius approximatus Blackburn, Rhizobius auranti
   Blackburn, Rhizobius vulgaris Weise, Rhizobius bilineatus Weise,
   Rhizobius breweri Crotch, Rhizobius corticalis Lea, Rhizobius caecus
   Blackburn, Rhizobius discipennis Blackburn, Rhizobius discoidalis Weise,
   Rhizobius dorsalis Blackburn, Rhizobius eminens Blackburn, Rhizobius
   confinis Lea, Rhizobius fasciculatus Blackburn, Rhizobius fugax
   Blackburn, Rhizobius gosfordensis Blackburn, Rhizobius insipidus
   Blackburn, Rhizobius laeticulus Blackburn, Rhizobius nigrovarius Lea,
   Rhizobius nitidus Blackburn, Rhizobius nubilus Weise, Rhizobius plebeius
   Blackburn, Rhizobius pulcher Blackburn, Rhizobius satelles Blackburn,
   Scymnus fagus, Broun, Rhizobius secessus Blackburn, Rhizobius speculifer
   Blackburn, Rhizobius subhirtellus Lea, Epilachna pulchella Montruzier,
   Rhizobius debilis Blackburn, Rhizobius lindi Blackburn, Rhizobius
   coeruleus Blackburn, Rhizobius umbratus Blackburn, Rhizobius brevicornis
   Weise. The following new species are described: Rhyzobius bielawskii, R.
   boothi, R. brunneus, R. calderi, R. dryandra, R. gingera, R. gordoni, R.
   greeni, R. josephi, R. leai, R. lineellus, R. micrus, R. macromaculatus,
   R. nataliae, R. newtonorum, R. pelion, R. popei, R. pseudopulcher, R.
   quadrimaculatus, R. rodmanni, R. reidi, R. similis, R. slipinski, R.
   unicolor, R. tasmanicus, R. tribulation, R. victoriensis, R. wanati, R.
   weiri from Australia and New Caledonia, R. bipunctatus, R. gonzalezi, R.
   iracildae, R. jayae, R. leucoceps, R. luciae, R. metallicus, R.
   papuensis, R. pooranii, R. violaceus from New Guinea, R. indicus, R.
   riedeli, R. sumatrensis from the Orient. Nomenclatural history,
   diagnoses and distribution are provided for each species. A keys to the
   species of the genus within the zoogeographical regions are presented.
   Rhyzobius gratus Weise, 1918 is treated here as species incertae sedis
   due to the unavailability of material for study.
C1 Tomaszewska, Wioletta; Museum and Institute of Zoology, Polish Academy
   of Sciences, Wilcza 64, 00-679 Warszawa, Poland, Poland.
EM wiolkat@miiz.waw.pl
PU Natura optima dux Foundation
PA Warszawa
SC Zoology
BN 978-83-930773-0-4

DT Article
TI [Parapinacoceras and Gymnites (Ammonoidea) enodis/posseckeri-Zone in the
   Upper Muschelkalk (Middle Triassic, Ladinian) Thuringia.]
FT Parapinacoceras und Gymnites (Ammonoidea) aus der enodis/posseckeri-Zone
   im Oberen Muschelkalk (Mittel-Trias, Ladin) Thueringens.
AU Rein, Siegfried (SRein@t-online.de) 
   Werneburg, Ralf
SO Semana
VL 25
PS 87-100
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB Alpine oxycone ammonites of the families Pinacoceratidae Motsisovics
   1879 and Gymnitidae WAAGEN 1895 are firstly presented from the
   enodis/posseckeri-zone of Upper Muschelkalk (Middle Triassic, Ladinian)
   in Thuringia. The immigrants are morphs of the genera Parapinacoceras
   DIENER 1916 and Gymnites MOJSISOVICS 1882. They are described after
   reproductive isolation in the Upper Muschelkalk-Sea of Thuringia as the
   new species Parapinacoceras thiemei n. sp. and Gymnites brunzeli n. sp.
   The more advanced shape of sutures in Parapinacoceras thiemei n. sp.
   corroborates the Ladinian age of the enodis/posseckerizone, because
   Parapinacoceras aspidoides from the Red Limestone of Schiechlingshohe
   near Hallstatt from the Anisian/Ladinian-boundary is phylogenetically
   more primitive and therefore biostratigraphically older. But the
   transitional region below the spinosus-zone is not automatically
   equivalent with the boundary of Anisian and Ladinian. The endemic
   development in the Germanic Basin does not permit a detailed correlation
   to the Anisian/Ladinian-boundary in the Tethyal Triassic. It is probably
   positioned only few above the Spiriferina-bed according to the find of
   Flexoptvchites in northern Wuerttemberg (URWCHS & KURZWELL 1997).
C1 Rein, Siegfried; Hubertusstr. 69, 99094 Erfurt-Rhoda, Germany, Germany.
EM SRein@t-online.de
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Buddhaites; Gymnites; Parapinacoceras [Environmental indicators /
   Stratigraphical indicators / systematics] [Zoogeography /
   Palaeobiogeography / ] [Triassic / Middle Triassic / distribution;
   stratigraphical distribution]. 
   Gymnites brunzeli; Parapinacoceras thiemei [Germany /  / new species]
   [Triassic /  / ].

TI Description of the first known fossil representative of the family
   Tanypezidae (Diptera: Schizophora).
AU Lonsdale, Owen (Owen.Lonsdale@agr.gc.ca) 
   Apigian, Kyle
SO Tijdschrift voor Entomologie
VL 153
IS 2
PS 213-216
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Neotanypeza dominicana sp. n., the first known fossil species in the
   family Tanypezidae (Diptera: Schizophora), is described and compared to
   extant species. The single male is preserved in Dominican amber, which
   dates to the mid Miocene at approximately 17-20MYO.

TI THREE NEW SNAILFISHES (SCORPAENIFORMES: LIPARIDAE) FROM BATHYAL DEPTHS
   OF THE ARCTIC.
AU Andriashev, A.P.
   Chernova, N.V. (chernova@zin.ru) 
SO Trudy Zoologicheskogo Instituta
VL 314
IS 4
PS 365-380
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of snailfishes caught in the Norwegian Sea south-west
   of Bear Island at a depth 1470 to 1695 m, are described. Careproctus
   moskalevi sp. nov. and Careproctus latiosus sp. nov. are most similar to
   C. micropus (Gunther, 1887) from the depths of Faroe Channel; they are
   included in subgenus Careproctula Andriashev 2003. Diagnosis of the
   endemic arctic genus Rhodichthys is corrected. The second species of
   this genus is described, Rhodichthys melanocephalus sp. nov.

TI POGONOPHRYNE BREVIBARBATA SP. NOV. (ARTEDIDRACONIDAE, NOTOTHENIOIDEI,
   PERCIFORMES) - A NEW SPECIES OF TOADLIKE PLUNDERFISH FROM THE ROSS SEA,
   ANTARCTICA.
AU Balushkin, A.V. (ichthlab@zin.ru) 
   Petrov, A.F.
   Prutko, V.G.
SO Trudy Zoologicheskogo Instituta
VL 314
IS 4
PS 381-386
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of notothenioid fish, Pogonophryne brevibarbata sp. nov.,
   from bathyal depths of the Ross Sea, Antarctica is described. The new
   species belongs to the "mentella" group of the genus Pogonophryne and is
   characterized by having a very short (not extended beyond nostril) and
   pointed mental barbel with a long (65[long dash]68 % of barbel length),
   narrow terminal expansion composed of low folds with serrated ridges.

PT J
AN ZOOR14704032668
DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF FRESHWATER FISHES OF THE GENUS ALBURNOIDES, A.
   FANGFANGAE AND A. DEVOLLI (ACTINOPTERYGII: CYPRINIDAE), FROM THE
   ADRIATIC SEA BASIN IN ALBANIA.
AU Bogutskaya, N.G. (nbogutskaya@rambler.ru) 
   Zupancic, P.
   Naseka, A.M.
SO Trudy Zoologicheskogo Instituta
VL 314
IS 4
PS 448-468
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Alburnoides are described from the river
   Seman drainage in the eastern Adriatic Sea basin in Albania. Both
   species have a pharyngeal tooth formula of 2.5[long dash]4.2.
   Alburnoides fangfangae, which occurs in the upper Osum river system, is
   distinguished from other members of the genus by a combination of
   characters including 11[half][long dash]13[half] anal fin branched rays,
   small scales numbering 46[long dash]53 in the total pored lateral line,
   total vertebrae usually 40 (20+20 and 21+19) or 41 (21+20 and 20+21),
   caudal peduncle depth 43[long dash]48% body depth at dorsal fin origin,
   usually a mostly or completely scaleless ventral keel, the mouth with a
   curved and only slightly slanted cleft and a produced fleshy snout, the
   interorbital width 1.3[long dash]1.5 times the eye diameter, a weakly
   ossified preethmoid, and a depressed and considerably expanded anterior
   tip of the basihyal (a unique feature among the western European
   Alburnoides). Alburnoides devolli, which is described from the upper
   Devoll river system, differs in having 11[half][long dash]13[half] anal
   fin branched rays, larger scales numbering 44[long dash]48 in the total
   pored lateral line, total vertebrae usually 40 (20+20), caudal peduncle
   depth 35[long dash]43% body depth at dorsal fin origin, usually a mostly
   or completely scaled ventral keel, the mouth with a straight and
   upturned cleft, the interorbital width 1.1[long dash]1.4 times the eye
   diameter, a completely ossified preethmoid, and a narrow, very deeply
   indented anterior tip of the urohyal (a unique feature among the western
   European Alburnoides). A comparison with Alburnoides species from River
   Danube and Prespa, Ohrid, and Skadar lakes is provided.
C1 Bogutskaya, N.G.; Zoological Institute of the Russian Academy of
   Sciences, Universitetskaya Emb. 1, 199034 Saint Petersburg, Russia,
   Russia.
EM nbogutskaya@rambler.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0206-0477

   region; Eurasia; Europe

DT Article
TI Some faunistic data on the bats of Italy.
AU Rehak, Zdenek (rehak@sci.muni.cz) 
SO Vespertilio
VL 13-14
PS 113-119
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During a spring trip across Italy in 1998, bats were surveyed using a
   bat detector and mist nets. The bats were recorded at seven localities,
   flying and foraging in various habitats or roosting in a shelter. In
   total, 6 bat species were netted, i.e. Rhinolophus ferrumequinum,
   Nyctalus leisleri, Pipistrellus pipistrellus, Pipistrellus nathusii,
   Barbastella barbastellus, and Plecotus auritus. At least 11 bat species
   were identified using the bat detector, i. e. Myotis daubentonii,
   Vespertilio murinus, Eptesicus serotinus, Nyctalus leisleri, Hypsugo
   savii, Pipistrellus pipistrellus, P. pygmaeus, P. nathusii, P. kuhlii,
   Barbastella barbastellus, and Plecotus sp. P. kuhlii seems to be a
   common species preferring lower elevations, in contrast with another
   common species H. savii which was mostly recorded at higher altitudes.
   The latter two species along with E. serotinus were often found foraging
   around street lamps. At the time of the survey, records of five species
   were new to the Gargano National Park. Data concerning V. murinus remain
   very rare for the whole Italy until now.
C1 Rehak, Zdenek; Department of Botany and Zoology, Faculty of Science,
   Masaryk University, Kotlarska 2, CZ-611 37 Brno, Czech Republic, Czech
   Republic.
EM rehak@sci.muni.cz
SC Zoology
SN 1213-6123

PT J
AN ZOOR14704032699
DT Article
TI Ammonites and ammonite stratigraphy of the Bimammatum Zone and lowermost
   Planula Zone (Submediterranean Upper Oxfordian).
AU Wierzbowski, Andrzej (andrzej.wierzbowski@uw.edu.pl) 
   Glowniak, Ewa
   Pietras, Krzysztof
SO Volumina Jurassica
VL 8
PS 49-76
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB An extensive collection of ammonites made bed by bed from sections in
   the Submediterranean Upper Oxfordian of the Wielun Upland, Central
   Poland, is described and used as a basis for a chronostratigraphical
   interpretation of the deposits. The ammonites are mostly of
   Submediterranean character and enable the recognition of the Bimammatum
   Zone, including the Bimammatum and Hauffianum subzones, as well as the
   lowermost Planula Zone distinguished here as a new biostratigraphical
   horizon [long dash] the matyjai horizon [long dash] based on the
   occurrence of Subnebrodites matyjai Wierzbowski et Glowniak sp. nov. The
   Submediterranean ammonites are mostly oppeliids with Taramelliceras
   (Taramelliceras) (M) [long dash] Glochiceras (Lingulaticeras) (m) the
   most numerous, as well as Taramelliceras (Richeiceras) and
   Taramelliceras (Metahaploceras) (M) [long dash] Glochiceras (Coryceras)
   (m). The profusion of ammonites of these two groups in the
   stratigraphical interval studied provides new information on their
   evolution, and two new oppeliid species, Taramelliceras (Taramelliceras)
   zelcense Wierzbowski et Glowniak sp. nov. and Glochiceras
   (Lingulaticeras) bobrownikiense Wierzbowski et Glowniak sp. nov., are
   described here. Subboreal and Boreal ammonites are not common in these
   sections, but are nevertheless important for correlation. Subboreal
   ammonites of the family Aulacostephanidae are represented by the genus
   Vineta (M), including its newly recognized microconchiate counterpart,
   Vineta (m), and a newly established genus Vielunia (M) Wierzbowski et
   Glowniak gen. nov., with type species Vielunia dzalosinensis Wierzbowski
   et Glowniak sp. nov. The latter genus includes ammonites previously
   referred in the area of study to Ringsteadia, and with a microconchiate
   counterpart assigned to Prorasenia (m). The Boreal ammonites comprise
   late cardioceratids assigned to Amoeboceras (Plasmatites). These
   ammonites indicate that the deposits in question from the
   Submediterranean Bimammatum Zone up to the Planula Zone correlate with
   the Subboreal and Boreal lowermost Kimmeridgian (Baylei Zone, and
   Bauhini Zone, respectively).
C1 Wierzbowski, Andrzej; Institute of Geology, University of Warsaw, ul.
   Zwirki i Wigury 93, 02-089 Warszawa, Poland, Poland.
EM andrzej.wierzbowski@uw.edu.pl
OI Glowniak, Ewa/0000-0001-8822-951X
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1896-7876
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Ammonoidea [Fossil assemblages /  / ] [Poland / Wielun Upland /
   stratigraphical distribution] [Jurassic / Upper Oxfordian / ]. 
   Glochiceras (Lingulaticeras) bobrownikiense; Taramelliceras
   (Taramelliceras) zelcense; Vielunia dzalosinensis [Poland /  / new

   Vielunia [Jurassic /  / New genus].

DT Article
TI Case report on Physaloptera alata infection in Botarous [Botaurus]
   stellaris from Iran.
AU Kordafshari, S.
   Samani, R.
   Hosseini, S.H.
   Youssefi, M.R.
   Esfandiari, B. (esfandiari88@hotmail.com) 
SO World Journal of Zoology
VL 5
IS 4
PS 246-248
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nematode believed to be Physaloptera sp. was found in one fish-eating
   bird (Botarous stellaris) examined from Fars Province from Iran. This is
   the first reported case of Physalopterid infection in fish-eating bird
   from Iran, yet 17 worms, which firmly were attached to gastric mucosa,
   were recovered from the bird gut and were associated with necrosis and a
   granulomatous reaction. Controversy exists about identification of worm
   and the role these birds play in the life history of physalopterid
   nematodes.
C1 Esfandiari, B.; Pasteur Institute of Iran-Amol Research Center, Iran.
EM esfandiari88@hotmail.com

   report; new record] [Iran /  / ].

LA German

PT J
AN ZOOR14704032919
DT Article
TI Two new species of Pileolaria (Polychaeta: Spirorbidae) from the
   Southern Hemisphere with a brief review of related species.
AU Rzhavsky, A.V. (rzhavskij@mail.ru) 
SO Zoologiya Bespozvonochnykh
VL 7
IS 2
PS 81-91
PD Dekabr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new polychaete species of family Spirorbidae are described, both
   similar to those species of Pileolaria that have the distal part of the
   brood-chamber smooth and domed or bilobed. Pileolaria connexa sp.n. from
   Kerguelen Island (and probably Palmer Archipelago), unlike most species
   of the genus, commonly retains the primary operculum (plate and talon)
   distal to the brood chamber, and has sickle chaetae with unusually long
   distal serrated parts of the blades. Pileolaria invultuosa sp.n. from
   Bouvet Island and Adelie Land (and perhaps Enderby Land and Signy
   Island) sheds the primary operculum before the brood chamber is fully
   developed and has distal serrated parts of sickle chaetae blades similar
   in length to proximal thick parts of the blades. Both new species are
   similar, but unusual amongst this group, in having a shallow calcified
   cap restricted to the distal part of the brood chamber. The primary
   opercula of both species differ from each other (and from those of most
   Pileolaria species) in the shape and position of the distal plates
   talons.
C1 Rzhavsky, A.V.; A.N. Severtsov Institute of Ecology and Evolution, RAS,
   Leninskij Prospekt 33, Moscow 119071, Russia, Russia.
EM rzhavskij@mail.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1812-9250; 1814-0815
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean;
   Indian Ocean
DE Pileolaria connexa [Antarctic Ocean /  / New species] [South Indian
   Ocean / Kerguelen Islands / ]. 
   Pileolaria invultuosa [Antarctic Ocean / Antarctica / New species]
   [South Atlantic / Bouvet Island / ]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Pileolaria connexa (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Kerguelen Islands (marine), P.
   83].

   87].

DT Article
TI A description of Anoplostoma nhatrangensis sp. n. from mangrove habitats
   of Nha Trang, Central Vietnam, with a review of the genus Anoplostoma
   Buetschli, 1874 (Nematoda: Enoplida).
AU Tchesunov, Alexei V. (AVTchesunov@yandex.ru) 
   Thanh, Nguyen Vu
SO Zoologiya Bespozvonochnykh
VL 7
IS 2
PS 93-105
PD Dekabr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Anoplostoma nhatrangensis sp.n. is described from a degrading mangrove
   habitat in the Nha Trang area, Central Vietnam. The new species is
   characterized by relatively long outer labial setae (81[long dash]120%
   c.b.d.); relatively long tail with longer posterior cylindrical portion
   (c 5.71[long dash]6.92, c' 8.96[long dash]11.8, distal tail part 63[long
   dash]90%); males without preanal bursal papillae and only a minute
   postanal bursal papilla besides the posterior bursal spine. Anoplostoma
   nhatrangensis sp.n. is most similar to the A. heterurum differing in
   certain morphometric values: a bit more stout body (a 33[long dash]45
   versus 56), and relatively longer tail (c 5.9[long dash]6.6 versus 11
   and c' 10[long dash]12 versus 6.5) with greater posterior slender
   cylindrical portion (82[long dash]90 versus 75%). A short taxonomic
   review of the Anoplostoma species is proposed. The genus contains twenty
   nominal species: fourteen of them are considered as valid; A.
   brevispiculum is considered as a species incertae sedis because its
   characters do not fit the generic diagnosis, A. demani as a species
   inquirenda because of incomplete data of the original description and A.
   macrospiculum as a junior synonym of A. sunderbanae. Tables of
   simplified images of male heads and tails as well as list of important
   morphometric values are proposed as a tool for quicker identification of
   Anoplostoma species.
C1 Tchesunov, Alexei V.; Department of Invertebrate Zoology, Faculty of
   Biology, Moscow State University, Moscow 119991, Russia, Russia.
EM AVTchesunov@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1812-9250; 1814-0815
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Anoplostoma nhatrangensis [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Anoplostoma - Buetschli 1874 (Nematoda): [Diagnostic characters,
   Species, p. 98; Included taxa, Annotated species list, p. 98]. 
   Anoplostoma brevispiculum - Sergeeva 1974 (Nematoda): [Taxonomic
   position, P. 98]. 
   Anoplostoma demani - Yimm 1952 (Nematoda): [Species inquirenda, P. 99]. 
   Anoplostoma macrospiculum - Sinha, Choudhury & Baqri 1987 (Nematoda):
   [Junior synonym, Of Anoplostoma sunderbanae Timm 1967, p. 100]. 
   Anoplostoma nhatrangensis (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 100].

   Anoplostoma macrospiculum Sinha, Choudhury & Baqri 1987, p. 100].

AN ZOOR14704032921
DT Article
TI Micronephthys (Polychaeta: Nephtyidae) of Northern Europe and Arctic.
AU Dnestrovskaya, N. Yu. (ndnestro@mail.ru) 
   Jirkov, I.A.
SO Zoologiya Bespozvonochnykh
VL 7
IS 2
PS 107-121
PD Dekabr 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Three species of Micronephthys inhabit Northern European and Arctic
   waters: Micronephthys minuta (Theel, 1879), M. neotena (Noyes, 1980),
   and M. hartmannschroederae Jirkov et Dnestrovskaya, 2001. All species
   are re-described, original illustrations and distribution maps accompany
   all descriptions. Micronephthys minuta and M. neotena are a mainly
   Arctic and boreal species, respectively, very abundant in brackish
   waters. Micronephthys hartmannschroederae should be very abundant
   sporadically in boreal European waters. The existing literature on
   biology and distribution of these species is reviewed. The taxonomic
   characters used to separate genera within Nephtyidae are analysed,
   proving that the family needs to be fully reviewed.
C1 Dnestrovskaya, N. Yu.; Moscow State University, Biological Faculty,
   Department of Hydrobiology, Leninskie Gory, 1, bldg. 12, Moscow 119991,
   Russia, Russia.

PT J
AN ZOOR14704030874
DT Article
TI Pliocene vertebrate fauna from karst fissures in Vitosov, northern
   Moravia (the Czech Republic).
FT Pliocenni fauna obratlovcu z krasovych vyplni vapencoveho lomu ve
   Vitosove na severni Morave.
AU Cermak, Stanislav (cermaks@gli.cas.cz) 
   Wagner, Jan
   Moravek, Rostislav
   Fejfar, Oldrich
   Horacek, Ivan
SO Zpravy Vlastivedneho Muzea v Olomouci
VL 299
PS 20-36
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Czech
U1 0
U2 0
AB The limestone quarry in Vitosov located within Zabreh in Moravia
   district (Northern Moravia, Czech Republic) is an important karst
   geology site of Northern Moravian region. The limestone quarry is still
   disclosing several vertical fissures and small caves infilled by terra
   rossa and cemented debris, which yielded separated faunal assemblages.
   Taxonomic composition and phenotypic characteristic of particular taxa
   support the same age of them and, tentatively, allow us to consider the
   whole assemblage as a single faunal unit. Until now, we have obtained
   about 200 determinable specimens of at least 26 mammalian taxa from the
   locality. The fauna is characterized by dominance of diversified
   insectivores and bats. The co-occurrence of Desmanella sp., Beremendia
   fissidens, Blarinoides mariae, and Marine/la cf. europaea among
   insectivores, as well as a relatively high percentage of shrews, is
   characteristic for the upper part of Early Pliocene (MN 15). This
   association closely resembles the situation described from localities
   Csarnota 2 and Gundersheim. Also, in bats the phenotypic characteristics
   correspond to those in forms reported from Gundersheim or Wgze and are
   preliminarily co-identified with them (Rhinolophus cf. lissiensis,
   Myotis cf. gundersheimensis, Myotis cf. podlesicensis, etc.). On the
   contrary, rodents are relatively rare. Except for Germanomys welled and
   Baranomys sp., the archaic taxa of cricetids, two forms of Mimomys were
   identified. M. hassiacus and an advanced form of M. gracilis provided
   the most important evidence for the geological age of the locality. The
   latter is slightly more advanced compared to M. gracilis from Csarnota
   2, Wolfersheim or Ivanovice (MN 15b); simultaneously, it seems more
   primitive than M. stehlini from Hajnacka (MN 16a). Thus, the species
   composition, as well as the structure of the fauna, suggests the age
   near the Late Ruscinian (MN 15b) [long dash] Early Villanyian (MN 16a)
   boundary, i.e. time span ca. 3.3[long dash]4.0 Mya. From the
   paleoecological point of view the fossil record in Vitosov suggests
   presence of highly diversified humid biotopes with substantial rate of
   broad-leaved woods; the situation well corresponding with present view
   of paleoenvironmental conditions during the Early Pliocene. The new
   material enlarges our knowledge about this relatively poorly understood
   period of mammalian evolution in Central Europe.
C1 Cermak, Stanislav; Geologicky ustav AV CR, v. v. i., Rozvojova 269, 165
   02 Praha 6-Lysolaje, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM cermaks@gli.cas.cz
RI Wagner, Jan/N-2070-2014; Cermak, Stanislav/I-8763-2014
OI Cermak, Stanislav/0000-0002-0974-2065
SC Zoology; Paleontology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1212-1134
BD Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological
   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Micromammalia [Fossil assemblages / Assemblage composition / Karst
   fissures] [Environmental indicators / Palaeoenvironmental indications /
   ] [Czech Republic / Moravia, Vitosov / faunal list] [Pliocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia
OR Micromammalia (Mammalia): [Fossil].

DA 2020-09-17

DT Book
TI A conchological iconography. The Family Volutidae: the endemic Far East
   Asian subfamily Fulgorariinae Pilsbry & Olsson, 1954: a revision of the
   Recent species.
AU Bail, Patrice
   Chino, Mitsuo
BA Bail, Patrice
   Chino, Mitsuo
SO A conchological iconography. The Family Volutidae: the endemic Far East
   Asian subfamily Fulgorariinae Pilsbry & Olsson, 1954: a revision of the
   Recent species.
PS 1-74
PD 2010
PY 2010
NT Unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Recent endemic volutid fauna of Japanese waters, East China Sea and
   South China Sea is reviewed with emphasis on the genus Fulgoraria
   Schumacher, 1817, divided into 5 subgenera: 1) subgenus Fulgoraria with
   6 species: ericarum Doute, 1967; kaoae Bail, 2008; hamillei (Crosse,
   1871); humerosa Rehder, 1969; leviuscula Rehder, 1969; rupestris
   rupestris (Gmelin, 1791), rupestris politohumerosa Shikama, 1968,
   rupestris thachi n. ssp. 2) subgenus Musashia Hayashi, 1960 with 8
   species: allaryi Bail, 2005; cancellata Kuroda & Habe, 1950; carnicolor
   new species; chinoi Bail, 2000; clara (G. B. Sowerby III, 1914);
   formosana Azuma, 1967; hirasei (G. B. Sowerby, 1912); noguchii Hayashi,
   1960. 3) subgenus Kurodina Rehder, 1969 monospecific for smithi (G. B.
   Sowerby III, 1901). 4) subgenus Nipponomelon Shikama, 1967 which
   includes the highly polytypic species megaspira (G. B. Sowerby I, 1844)
   and its relative elongata Shikama, 1962. 5) subgenus Psephaea Crosse,
   1871 with 5 species: concinna (Broderip, 1836); daviesi (Fulton, 1938);
   kaneko Hirase, 1922; mentiens (Fulton, 1940) and possibly the Recent
   specimen of kamakurensis Otuka, 1949 described as a fossil. The other
   genus, Saotomea Habe, 1943 is divided into 2 subgenera: 1) subgenus
   Saotomea s.s. including delicata (Fulton, 1940); pratasensis Lan, 1997;
   solida Bail & Chino, 2000; hinae n. sp.. 2) the monospecific subgenus
   Bondarevia n. subgenus for Saotomea minima (Bondarev, 1994). The
   taxonomic position of the infraspecific names formerly applied and of
   the two elusive Japanese species Fulgoraria exoptanda and Fulgoraria
   kamakurensis is discussed.

DT Article
TI First observation of the red-breasted goose Branta ruficollis in
   Slovenia.
FT Prvo opazovanje rdecevrate gosi Branta ruficollis v Sloveniji.
AU Bordjan, Dejan (dejan.bordjan@gmail.com) 
SO Acrocephalus (Ljubljana)
VL 31
IS 144
PS 53-55
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA Slovenian
U1 0
U2 0
AB On 2 Nov 2008, a Red-breasted Goose Branta ruficollis was observed at
   Ptujsko jezero reservoir (UTM WM63, L NE Slovenia) while, a day later,
   presumably the same individual was noted and photographed at Medvedce p'
   reservoir (UTM WM53, NE Slovenia). These places are some 18 km apart.
   The observation is the first record of R the Red-breasted Goose's
   occurrence in Slovenia. It was confirmed by the National Rarities
   Committee, which placed the observation in Category A (Species recorded
   in an apparently natural state at least once since 1 Jan R 1950). In
   view of the fact that the bird appeared timid and was not ringed, the
   author presumes that a naturally occurring individual was at stake, in
   particular because R of the increasing trend of wintering populations
   moving towards the west and also because of the increasing number of
   observations made in the neighbouring countries. The article also
   presents the status of the species in the countries adjacent to
   Slovenia.
C1 Bordjan, Dejan; Nacionalni institut za biologijo, Vecna pot 111, SI-1000
   Ljubljana, Slovenia, Slovenia.
EM dejan.bordjan@gmail.com
SC Zoology

ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Anseriformes, Anatidae
OR Branta ruficollis (Anatidae): [New record].

TI Revision of the Afrotropical species of the Philonthus marginipennis
   species group (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Philonthina).
AU Hromadka, Lubomir (hromadkal@seznam.cz) 
SO Acta Societatis Zoologicae Bohemicae
VL 73
IS 1-2
PS 53-64
PD 2009(2010)
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Philonthus marginipennis species group of the genus Philonthus
   Stephens, 1829 containing seven species is proposed. One species is
   described as new: Philonthus estrilda sp. nov. (Democratic Republic of
   the Congo) and the other six species are redesribed: P. bangoranus
   Levasseur, 1980, P. capeneri Last, 1953, P. gilleti Levasseur, 1980, P.
   marginipennis Wollaston, 1867, P. sepilibilis Tottenham, 1949 and P.
   upuzius Tottenham, 1962. A key to all the species of the P.
   marginipennis species group is presented and the aedeagi and relevant
   morphological characters of all species are figured.
C1 Hromadka, Lubomir; Anny Letenske 7, CZ-120 00 Praha 2, Czech Republic,
   Czech Republic.
EM hromadkal@seznam.cz
SC Zoology
SN 1211-376X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Philonthus estrilda [Congo-Kinshasa /  / New species]. 
   Philonthus marginipennis species group [Afrotropical region /  /
   Distribution; systematic revision]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae

   P. 54]. 
   Philonthus capeneri - Last 1953 (Staphylinidae): [Redescription, P. 56].
   
   Philonthus estrilda (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Congo-Kinshasa, P. 57]. 
   Philonthus gilleti - Levasseur 1980 (Staphylinidae): [Redescription, P.
   58].

   [Redescription, P. 59]. 
   Philonthus marginipennis species group (Staphylinidae): [Diagnosis, P.
   53; Key to species, P. 63]. 
   Philonthus sepilibilis - Tottenham 1949 (Staphylinidae): [Redescription,
   P. 60]. 
   Philonthus upuzius - Tottenham 1962 (Staphylinidae): [Redescription, P.
   62].

PT J
AN ZOOR14703022297
DT Article
TI Contribution to the recognition of Cerambycidae (Coleoptera).
AU Slama, Milan E.F. (m.e.f.slama@seznam.cz) 
SO Biocosme Mesogeen
VL 27
IS 3
PS 74-86
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The autor present a description of a new species Anoplistes
   Audinet-Serville, 1934 from Bulgaria. Because of the significant
   difference from Paracorymbia maculicornis (De Geer, 1775) and
   Paracorymbia simplonica (Fairmaire, 1885) the Paracorymbia ondreji
   (Slama, 1993) is classified as an independant species. A description of
   Poecilium pusillum (Fabricius, 1787) inopinatum ssp. n. from Greece is
   included.
C1 Slama, Milan E.F.; U Skolske zahrady 718/3, 182 00 Praha 8 - Kobylisy,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM m.e.f.slama@seznam.cz
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0762-6428
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Status;
   Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Anoplistes balcanicus [Bulgaria /  / New species]. 
   Poecilium pusillum inopinatum [Plant hosts / Quercus / New parasite
   subspecies] [Greece /  / New subspecies from plant host]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Anoplistes balcanicus (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Bulgaria, P. 75]. 
   Poecilium pusillum inopinatum (Cerambycidae): [Subsp nov, Greece,
   Parasite of Quercus (Plant), p. 82; Parasite]. 
   Poecilium pusillum pusillum - (Fabricius 1787) (Cerambycidae):
   [Diagnosis, P. 84]. 
   Stictoleptura (Paracorymbia) ondreji - (Slama 1993) (Cerambycidae):
   [Diagnostic characters, P. 79; Raised from, Stictoleptura (Paracorymbia)
   simplonica ondreji, p. 79]. 
   Stictoleptura (Paracorymbia) simplonica ondreji - (Slama 1993)
   (Cerambycidae): [Raised to, Stictoleptura (Paracorymbia) ondreji, p.
   79].

PT J
AN ZOOR14703022299
DT Article
TI Description of Strophosoma boroveci n. sp. (Coleoptera, Curculionidae)
   from Morocco.
FT Description of Strophosma boroveci n. sp. (Coleoptera, Curculionidae) du
   Maroc.
AU Pelletier, Jean
SO Biocosme Mesogeen
VL 27
IS 3
PS 88-92
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new Strophosoma, S. horoveci n. sp., belonging to the sub-genus
   Strophosoma s. str. is described from the moroccan Moyen Atlas. This
   taxon is easily recognized versus the other species of the subgenus by
   the presence of a large brilliant granule in the middle of the pronotum
   basis in the [female]. In the [male], the median lobe of penis, is also
   characteristic of the species. A simplified dichotomic key is given,
   allowing the identification of the new species among the Strophosoma s.
   str. from Morocco.
C1 Pelletier, Jean; 5, rue de la saulaie, F-37380 Monnaie, France, France.
SC Zoology
SN 0762-6428
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Africa
DE Strophosoma (Strophosoma) [Morocco /  / Key to species]. 
   Strophosoma (Strophosoma) boroveci [Morocco /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Strophosoma (Strophosoma) - Billberg 1820 (Curculionidae): [Key to
   species, Morocco, P. 92]. 
   Strophosoma (Strophosoma) boroveci (Curculionidae): [Sp nov, Morocco, P.
   89].
