   Burmelcana longirostris, p. 89, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Burmelcana longirostris (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Myanmar, Cretaceous, P.
   90, Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Hispanelcana (Saltatoria): [Gen nov, Of family Elcanidae, Type species
   Hispanelcana arilloi, p. 92, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Hispanelcana alavensis (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P. 94,
   Described from amber; Fossil]. 
   Hispanelcana arilloi (Saltatoria): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P. 92,

DT Article
TI A new genus of sphaeropsocid bark lice from the Early Cretaceous amber
   of Lebanon (Psocodea: Sphaeropsocidae).
AU Azar, Dany (azar@mnhn.fr) 
   Engel, Michael S.
   Grimaldi, David A.
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 103-107
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new genus and species of sphaeropsocid bark louse is described and
   figured from a single individual in Early Cretaceous amber from Hammana,
   central Lebanon. Asphaeropsocites neli gen. n., sp. n. is the second
   sphaeropsocid described from Lebanese amber. Like Sphaeropsocites
   lebanensis Grimaldi & Engel 2006, it has a basal phylogenetic position
   within Sphaeropsocidae, and adds evidence that these insects were once
   widespread and global, in the past. The new species is distinguished
   from related taxa, and a discussion and checklist of sphaeropsocids are
   provided.
C1 Azar, Dany; Lebanese University, Faculty of Sciences II, Department of
   Natural Sciences, Fanar-Matn, P.O. box 26110217, Lebanon, Lebanon.

TI A new Early Cretaceous snakefly (Raphidioptera: Mesoraphidiidae) from El
   Soplao amber (Spain).
AU Perez-de la Fuente, Ricardo (perezdelafuente@ub.edu) 
   Nel, Andre
   Penalver, Enrique
   Delclos, Xavier
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 108-115
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A virtually complete specimen of the family Mesoraphidiidae (Insecta:
   Raphidioptera) is described as Cantabroraphidia marcanoi n. gen., n. sp.
   It was found in early Albian amber from a new deposit named El Soplao
   within the Las Penosas Fm. in northwestern Cantabria (Spain). It has
   been compared to all adult fossils placed in the Mesozoic family
   Mesoraphidiidae. Some taxonomical comments are provided, and we propose
   to restore the genus Yanoraphidia Ren 1995 and the combination
   Yanoraphidia gaol Ren 1995 stat. rest., provisionally retained in the
   family Mesoraphidiidae.

DT Article
TI Pachnobium dreuxi, n. g., n. sp. discovered as a fossil and still living
   in the Crozet Islands (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Ectemnorrhininae).
FT Pachnobium dreuxi n. g., n. sp., ses occurrences modernes et fossiles
   sur l'archipel Crozet (Coleoptere Curculionidae Ectemnorrhininae).
AU Chapelin-Viscardi, Jean-David (j-d.chapelin-viscardi@hotmail.fr) 
   Voisin, Jean-Francois
   Ponel, Philippe
   Van der Putten, Nathalie
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 125-131
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 6
AB Pachnobium dreuxi, n. g., n. sp. discovered as a fossil and still living
   in the Crozet Islands (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Ectemnorrhininae).
   Pachnobium dreuxi, a new genus and species of Ectemnorrhininae weevil,
   was first discovered as a fossil in a Holocene sedimentary sequence at
   lie de la Possession (Crozet Islands, southern Indian Ocean). Two modern
   specimens were subsequently found in the collections of the Museum
   national d'Histoire naturelle (Paris). Pachnobium dreuxi n. g., n. sp.
   differs readily from all other species of the subfamily by its rostrum
   deeply emarginated at the apex, massive head, reduced sclerotinization,
   straight and flattened foretibiae, etc. Its biology and ecology are
   almost completely unknown, although some aspects of its morphology such
   as its reduced sclerotinization and relatively small eyes argue for a
   hidden life among vegetal debris or in cavities of the ground like
   petrel nests. The paleoenvironmental reconstruction suggests that this
   species lives in densely vegetated habitats. The two modern specimens
   were collected in two widely separated islands, Ile de l'Est and Ile des
   Pingouins, but the lack of modern captures on Possession Island raises
   the question of its continued presence there.
C1 Chapelin-Viscardi, Jean-David; Museum Natl Hist Nat, USM 305, CP 305, 57
   Rue Cuvier, Paris, France, France.
EM j-d.chapelin-viscardi@hotmail.fr
RI Ponel, Philippe/J-6000-2014
OI Van der Putten, Nathalie/0000-0002-0271-9321
SC Zoology
SN 0037-9271
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oceanic islands; Indian
   Ocean islands; French Southern Territories
DE Pachnobium dreuxi [Crozet Islands /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae

   Type species Pachnobium dreuxi, p. 126]. 
   Pachnobium dreuxi (Curculionidae): [Sp nov, Crozet Islands, P. 128]. 
DI 10.1080/00379271.2010.10697647

TI Hispanothrips from Early Cretaceous Spanish amber, a new genus of the
   resurrected family Stenurothripidae (Insecta: Thysanoptera).
AU Penalver, Enrique (penalver@uv.es) 
   Nel, Patricia
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 138-147
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB During a palaeontological excavation of amber at the site named San
   Just, in the Utrillas-Escucha area of Teruel Province, northeastern
   Spain, a rich fauna from the Albian (Early Cretaceous) was discovered.
   Among it, three specimens of Thysanoptera were found that are here
   attributed to the new genus Hispanothrips n. gen. in the family
   Stenurothripidae Bagnall 1923. Phylogenetic analyses were conducted that
   support the resurrection of the family Stenurothripidae and its
   replacement for Adiheterothripidae Shumsher 1946.

   Rosas 23, Madrid, Spain, Spain.

TI The first Praesiricidae (Hymenoptera) from Northeast China.
AU Gao, Taiping
   Rasnitsyn, Alexander P.
   Ren, Dong (rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn) 
   Shih, Chungkun
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 148-153
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new subfamily Rudisiricinae Gao, Rasnitsyn, Ren & Shih, n. subfam. and
   a new genus Rudisiricius Gao, Rasnitsyn, Ren & Shih, n. gen. with three
   new species R. belli, Rasnitsyn, Ren & Shih n. sp., R. crassinodus Gao,
   Rasnitsyn, Ren & Shih, n. sp., and R. celsus Gao, Rasnitsyn, Ren & Shih,
   n. sp. are described and illustrated from the family Praesiricidae. The
   type specimens were collected from the Late Jurassic to Early Cretaceous
   Yixian Formation, northeastern China. The new subfamily also includes
   Aulidontes Rasnitsyn from the Upper Jurassic of Karatau in Kazakhstan.
   This is the first record of Praesiricidae in China. These well-preserved
   nearly-complete new fossils reported here provide additional material
   and structure characters about this family, which helps filling some gap
   in the evolution of Lower Hymenoptera.
C1 Ren, Dong; Capital Normal Univ, Key Lab Insect Evolut & Environm
   Changes, Beijing, China, China.
EM rendong@mail.cnu.edu.cn
RI Rasnitsyn, Alexandr/P-2393-2015; Gao, Taiping/Z-3987-2019
OI Rasnitsyn, Alexandr/0000-0002-6350-0040
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0037-9271
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic

PT J
AN ZOOR14610072077
DT Article
TI Modern thrips families Thripidae and Phlaeothripidae in Early Cretaceous
   amber (Insecta: Thysanoptera).
AU Nel, Patricia (pnel@mnhn.fr) 
   Penalver, Enrique
   Azar, Dany
   Hodebert, Gilbert
   Nel, Andre
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 154-163
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Two specimens of Thysanoptera with forked sensilla on third and fourth
   antennal segments were described from the Lebanese Neocomian and the
   Spanish Albian ambers, and attributed to the new genus Tethysthrips n.
   gen. in the family Thripidae Stevens 1829. One specimen with a tubular
   tenth abdominal segment was also discovered in the Lebanese Neocomian
   amber, and attributed to the new genus Rohrthrips n. gen. belonging to
   the family Phlaeothripidae Uzel 1895. Thripidae and Phlaeothripidae are
   nowadays the most species-rich families of Thysanoptera. The present
   discoveries of Early Cretaceous fossils show how diversified these
   families and thrips already were at that time. Moreover, this
   tubuliferan Rohrthrips specimen has plesiomorphies no longer present in
   the recent genera, in particular on the wings. Therefore it brings new
   insight in the evolution of Tubulifera.
C1 Nel, Patricia; AgroParisTech, CP 50,45 Rue Buffon, Paris, France,
   France.
EM pnel@mnhn.fr
RI Azar, Dany L/E-4154-2010; Azar, Dany/AAF-7387-2020

TI Lobateuchus, a new fossil dung beetle genus from the northern France
   (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae, Scarabaeinae).
FT Lobateuchus, un nouveau genre de 'bousier' fossile du nord de la France
   (Coleoptera : Scarabaeidae, Scarabaeinae).
AU Montreuil, Olivier (o.montr@mnhn.fr) 
   Genier, Francois
   Nel, Andre
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 164-167
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 4
AB Lobateuchus, a new fossil dung beetle genus from the northern France
   (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae, Scarabaeinae). Lobateuchus parisii n. gen.,
   n. sp. is described from Lower Eocene Oise amber, in the vicinity of
   Paris. The discovery of this fossil questions the strict Gondwanian
   distribution of the Ateuchini.

DT Article
TI Diplocoelus probiphyllus n. sp., the first known fossil false skin
   beetle (Coleoptera: Biphyllidae).
AU Vitali, Francesco (vitalfranz@yahoo.de) 
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 168-172
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The first fossil species of the family Biphyllidae LeConte 1861,
   Diplocoelus probiphyllus n. sp., is described from Baltic amber. This
   species, which shows intermediate characters of antennae, sculpturing
   and pubescence between Diplocoelus Guerin-Meneville 1844 and Biphyllus
   Dejean 1821, also suggests the presence of temperate mixed forests and a
   climate cooler than it has been until today hypothesised for Baltic
   Amber.
C1 Vitali, Francesco; Corso Torino 5-7, Genoa, Italy, Italy.
EM vitalfranz@yahoo.de

   amber] [Oligocene /  / ].

DT Article
TI Revision of the scorpionfly family Holcorpidae (Mecoptera), with
   description of a new species from Early Eocene McAbee, British Columbia,
   Canada.
AU Archibald, S. Bruce (sba48@sfu.ca) 
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 173-182
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The scorpionfly family Holcorpidae (Mecoptera) has been informally
   discussed since the early 1960's, but a detailed treatment in accordance
   with the provisions of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature
   for naming families was not provided until Willmann did so in 1989; he
   is recognized as author of the family. The Holcorpidae concept is
   revised here based on examination of its two specimens of Holcorpa
   maculosa from the Late Eocene of Florissant, Colorado, and a third, new
   specimen from the Early Eocene Okanagan Highlands locality at McAbee,
   British Columbia, Canada. This new specimen belongs to a second, new
   species, which is described here, Holcorpa dillhoffi n. sp.
C1 Archibald, S. Bruce; Simon Fraser Univ, Dept Biol Sci, 8888 Univ Dr,
   Burnaby, BC, Canada, Canada.
EM sba48@sfu.ca
SC Zoology
SN 0037-9271

   region; North America; Canada; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene

   Holcorpidae [North America / West / biology; distribution;
   stratigraphical distribution; systematics] [Eocene / Ypresian-Priabonian
   / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Mecoptera

   181; Fossil]. 
   Holcorpidae - Willmann 1989 (Mecoptera): [Emended diagnosis, P. 175;
   Fossil].

DT Article
TI New griffenfly, Bohemiatupus elegans from the Late Carboniferous of
   western Bohemia in the Czech Republic (Odonatoptera: Meganisoptera:
   Meganeuridae).
AU Prokop, Jakub (jprokop@natur.cuni.cz) 
   Nel, Andre
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 183-188
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new griffenfly, Bohemiatupus elegans n. gen., n. sp. (Meganeuridae) is
   described from the Upper Carboniferous (Bolsovian) deposits of the vein
   near Radnice in western Bohemia (Czech Republic). The new taxon based on
   fore- and hindwing venation is compared with the other meganeurid
   genera. It is the first record of a large griffenfly from the
   continental basins of the Bohemian Massif supplementing the other giant
   insects such as Bojophlebia prokopi Kukalova-Peck 1985 or Carbotriplura
   kukalovae Kluge 1996 from the same strata.
C1 Prokop, Jakub; Charles Univ, Fac Sci, Vinicna 7, Prague, Czech Republic,
   Czech Republic.
EM jprokop@natur.cuni.cz

   Cretaceous amber of Lebanon.

   Nel, Andre

U1 0
U2 0
AB The schizopterid bug Libanohypselosoma popovi n. gen., n. sp. belonging
   to the subfamily Hypselosomatinae is described from the Lower Cretaceous
   amber of Lebanon. This fossil is the earliest record of the
   Schizopteridae. The species is distinguished from its related taxa, a
   discussion is given.

DT Article
TI Two new non-biting midges from the Early Cretaceous Lebanese amber
   (Diptera: Chironomidae).
AU Azar, Dany (azar@mnhn.ft) 
   Nel, Andre
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 198-203
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two chironomid flies, Ziadeus kamili n. gen., n. sp. and Paicheleria
   magnifica n. gen., n. sp., respectively attributed to the recent
   subfamilies Tanypodinae and Prodiamesinae, are described from the Early
   Cretaceous Lebanese amber. Although very old, this non-biting midge
   fauna was very diverse with no less than 11 genera and species. However,
   it was also strongly different from the recent faunas for the complete
   absence of the Chironominae, that is today the dominant subfamily. The
   development of the modern chironomid fauna occurred during the Late
   Cretaceous and/or the Early Paleogene, but when and how?
C1 Azar, Dany; Lebanese Univ, Fac Sci 2, POB 26110217, Fanar Matn, Lebanon,
   Lebanon.
EM azar@mnhn.ft
RI Azar, Dany/AAF-7387-2020; Azar, Dany L/E-4154-2010

SC Zoology
SN 0037-9271

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Described from amber] [Cretaceous /  / ].

TI New Tridactyloidea in Miocene amber from the Dominican Republic
   (Orthoptera: Caelifera).
AU Heads, Sam W. (swheads@illinois.edu) 
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 204-210
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Two new Tridactyloidea of the families Ripipterygidae and Tridactylidae
   are described from the Early Miocene (Burdigalian) amber of the
   Dominican Republic, namely: Archaeoellipes engeli n. gen., n. sp.
   (Tridactylidae: Tridactylinae) and Mirhipipteryx antillarum n. sp.
   (Ripipterygidae). These new taxa represent the first record of
   Tridactyloidea in Dominican amber and the first fossil record of
   Ripipterygidae, which are otherwise known only from the extant fauna.

DT Article
TI A new rhopalosomatid wasps in the Paleocene of France (Hymenoptera).
AU Nel, Andre (anel@mnhn.fr) 
   Azar, Dany
   Hervet, Sophie
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 211-215
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The third oldest Rhopalosomatidae, Paleorhopalosoma menatensisn. gen.,
   n. sp., is described from the Paleocene of Menat (France). In addition
   to the characters unique to rhopalosomatids the plesiomorphic complete
   wing venation together with plesiomorphic shape of metasoma show that
   this genus is very likely a more 'basal' clade of this family, together
   with the Early Cretaceous genus Mesorhopalosoma.
C1 Nel, Andre; Museum Natl Hist Nat, CNRS, CP 50,45 Rue Buffon, Paris,
   France, France.

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene

AN ZOOR14610072087
DT Article
TI New Archostemata (Insecta: Coleoptera) from the French Paleocene and
   Early Eocene, with a note on the composition of the suborder.
AU Kirejtshuk, Alexander G. (agk@zin.ru) 
   Nel, Andre
   Collomb, Francois-Marie
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 216-227
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The paper deals with descriptions of four new species of Archostemata
   from the Paleocene and Earliest Eocene amber, Cupes manifestus n. sp.,
   C. orbiculatus n. sp., C. ponomarenkoi n. sp. and Micromalthus eocenicus
   n. sp., the latter representing the oldest member of genus Micromalthus
   Leconte 1878 (Micromalthidae). The position, composition and origin of
   the genera Cupes and Micromalthus are considered. Cupes seemed to appear
   during Cretaceous or very close to this period, while Micromalthus could
   originate somewhat later. The synonymy of Cupedini and Priacmini is
   grounded. The genus Crowsoniella Pace 1975 (Crowsoniellidae) could be
   excluded from the suborder Archostemata and transferred into the
   infraorder Cucujiformia (Polyphaga).
C1 Kirejtshuk, Alexander G.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Emb 1,
   St Petersburg, Russia, Russia.
EM agk@zin.ru
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0037-9271
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Archostemata [Phylogeny /  / Systematics]. 
   Cupes manifestus; Cupes orbiculatus; Cupes ponomarenkoi [France /  / new
   species] [Palaeogene /  / ]. 
   Micromalthus eocenicus [France /  / new species; Described from amber]
   [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Archostemata, Cupedoidea,
   Cupedidae, Micromalthidae
OR Archostemata (Coleoptera). 
   Cupes manifestus (Cupedidae): [Sp nov, France, Palaeogene, P. 219;
   Fossil]. 
   Cupes orbiculatus (Cupedidae): [Sp nov, France, Palaeogene, P. 220;
   Fossil]. 
   Cupes ponomarenkoi (Cupedidae): [Sp nov, France, Palaeogene, P. 222;
   Fossil]. 
   Micromalthus eocenicus (Micromalthidae): [Sp nov, France, Eocene, P.
   223, Described from amber; Fossil]. 
DI 10.1080/00379271.2010.10697661
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14610072087

PT J
AN ZOOR14610072088
DT Article
TI Afrotropical and Nearctic genera of Odonata in the French Oligocene:
   biogeographic and paleoclimatic implications (Insecta: Calopterygidae,
   Aeshnidae).
AU Nel, Andre (anel@mnhn.fr) 
   Petrulevicius, Julian F.
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 228-236
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB New species of the genera Sapho and Epiaeschna are recorded in the
   Oligocene of Aixen-Provence, Bouches-du-Rhone, France. Sapho legrandi n.
   sp. is the third fossil representative of this recent African genus and
   Epiaeschna pseudoheros n. sp. is the fifth fossil species of this recent
   North American genus. The fossil species Triaeschna gossi from the
   Eocene of England, Epacantha magnifica from the Late Oligocene of
   Kazakhstan, and Mediaeschna matutina from the Oligocene of China, are
   considered species of Epiaeschna and the three fossil genera Triaeschna
   Campion 1916, Mediaeschna Zhang 1989, and Epacantha Martynov 1929 are
   synonymized with Epiaeschna. The closely related genera umma and Sapho
   inhabit warm humid forests of Western Africa. Their presence in two
   Oligocene deposits of France supports the hypothesis of a warm humid
   palaeoenvironment for Armissan (Aude, France), and Aix-en-Provence.
C1 Nel, Andre; Museum Natl Hist Nat, CNRS, 45 Rue Buffon, Paris, France,
   France.
EM anel@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 0037-9271

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Epiaeschna; Sapho [Abiotic factors / Palaeoenvironment / ] [Zoogeography
   / Palaeobiogeography / ] [Land zones /  / ]. 
   Epiaeschna pseudoheros; Sapho legrandi [France /  / new species]

   230; Syn nov, Mediaeschna Zhang 1989, p. 230; Syn nov, Triaeschna
   Campion 1916, p. 230]. 
   Epiaeschna gossi - (Campion 1916) (Odonata): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Triaeschna, p. 234]. 
   Epiaeschna magnifica - (Martynov 1929) (Odonata): [Redescription, P.

AB Lusitaneura covensis n. gen., n. sp., from the Late Carboniferous (Lower
   Stephanian C) of the Douro Basin (NW of Portugal), is the first

DT Article
TI Recent genus Notonecta (Insecta: Heteroptera: Notonectidae) in the Lower
   Cretaceous of San Luis, Argentina: palaeoecological implications.
AU Petrulevicius, Julian F. (levicius@museo.fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Nel, Andre
   Soledad Sallenave, Ana
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 247-253
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a new species of the genus Notonecta, i.e. Notonecta
   mazzoniae n. sp. from the Lower Cretaceous of Argentina. It is the first
   fossil representative of the family described from South America,
   demonstrating the great antiquity of the genus, bearing identical
   ventral chaetal system correlated wih respiratory for such a long
   period. The new species is recorded only by immature stages from the
   second to the fifth instars. Specimens are considered to be exuviae and
   not body fossils. Absence of body fossils may be due to taphonomic bias
   instead of palaeoecological constrains. In addition we found some
   specimens of Anisopinae, also considered as nymph exuviae, which
   represent the oldest record of the taxon.
C1 Petrulevicius, Julian F.; Natl Univ La Plata, Museo La Plata, Paseo
   Bosque S-N, La Plata, Argentina, Argentina.
EM levicius@museo.fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
SC Zoology
SN 0037-9271
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Notonecta mazzoniae [Argentina /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Notonectidae [South America /  / new record] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Nepomorpha,
   Notonectoidea, Notonectidae
OR Notonectidae (Notonectoidea): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Notonecta mazzoniae (Notonectidae): [Sp nov, Argentina, Cretaceous, P.
   249; Fossil]. 
DI 10.1080/00379271.2010.10697665

TI New psychopsoid Neuroptera from the Early Cretaceous of Baissa,
   Transbaikalia.
AU Makarkin, Vladimir N. (vnmakarkin@mail.ru) 
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 254-261
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new genera and five new species of the psychopsoid Neuroptera (one
   of which is unnamed) are described from the Early Cretaceous locality at
   Baissa, Transbaikalia, Russia: Epipsychopsis fusca n. gen., n. sp., E.
   variegate n. sp. (Psychopsidae), Pseudopsychopsis gradata n. gen., n.
   sp., P. baissensis n. sp. (Brongniartiellidae), and Sophogramma sp.
   (Kalligrammatidae).

AN ZOOR14610072094
DT Article
TI A new genus and species of darner dragonfly (Aeshnidae: Odonata) from
   the Lower Eocene of Laguna del Hunco, Patagonia, Argentina.
AU Petrulevicius, Julian F. (levicius@mnhn.fr) 
   Nel, Andre
   Voisin, Jean-Francois
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 1-2
PS 271-275
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new genus of Aeshnidae, Huncoaeshna n. gen., based on Huncoaeshna
   corrugata n. gen., n. sp., is erected from Laguna del Hunco (Ypresian)
   in Patagonia Argentina. The specimen presents a special kind of
   preservation with the middle part of the wing wrinkled. The presence of
   only two fossil specimens of Aeshnidae in South America is surely due to
   the lack of paleontomologists and collections of fossil insects in the
   subcontinent.
C1 Petrulevicius, Julian F.; Museum Natl Hist Nat, CNRS, 45 Rue Buffon,
   Paris, France, France.
EM levicius@mnhn.fr
SC Zoology

   South America; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

   Huncoaeshna corrugata, p. 271, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Huncoaeshna corrugata (Odonata): [Sp nov, Argentina, Eocene, P. 273;

AN ZOOR14712083980
DT Article
TI Sap beetles of the tribe Mystropini (Coleoptera: Nitidulidae) associated
   with South American palm inflorescences.
AU Kirejtshuk, Alexander G. (Kirejtshuk@gmail.com) 
   Couturier, Guy
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 3-4
PS 367-421
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 1
U2 13
AB The paper is devoted to the complex of pollinators from the tribe
   Mystropini collected on the infl orescences of the palms, cultivated or
   growing under natural conditions in South America, which includes
   Anthepurops depressa Kirejtshuk 1996; Anthocorcina subcalva Kirejtshuk &
   Jelnek 2000; Mystrops astrocaryi Kirejtshuk & Couturier n. sp.; M.
   atrata Kirejtshuk & Couturier n. sp.; M. bactrii Kirejtshuk & Couturier
   n. sp.; M. beserrai Kirejtshuk & Couturier n. sp.; M. costaricensis
   Gillogly 1972; M. dalmasi (Grouvelle 1902) n. comb.; M. delgadoi
   Kirejtshuk & Couturier 2009; M. discoidea Murray 1864; M. gigas
   Kirejtshuk & Couturier 2009; M. hisamatsui Kirejtshuk & Couturier 2009;
   M. kahni Kirejtshuk & Couturier n. sp.; M. komissari Kirejtshuk &
   Couturier n. sp.; M. lobanovi Kirejtshuk & Couturier n. sp.; M. neli
   Kirejtshuk & Couturier 2009; M. pectoralis Kirejtshuk, Couturier &
   Jelnek n. sp.; M. pulchra Kirejtshuk & Couturier 2009; M. rotundula
   Sharp 1889; M. squamae Kirejtshuk & Couturier n. sp.; M. vasquezi
   Kirejtshuk & Couturier n. sp.; Platychorodes adentatus Kirejtshuk &
   Couturier n. sp. The synonymy of the taxa is established. Mystrops
   corpulenta Jelnek 1969 is very similar and could be a variety of M.
   rotundula Sharp 1899. Palaeocorcina Jelnek & Kirejtshuk 2000 n. stat. is
   regarded as a separate genus. Lectotype are designated for Mystrops
   costaricensis pacifi cus, M. c. orientalis, M. debilis, M. discoidea, M.
   fl avicans, M. insularis and Priops mexicanus. Diagnosis for larva of
   the tribe Mystropini is elaborated on base of the redescription of
   mature larva of M. debilis. The pollinators from the tribe Mystropini
   were studied from the next cultivated palms Astrocaryum vulgare, Bactris
   gasipaes and Elaeis oleifera; from the next palms in natural forests:
   Aiphanes ulei, Astrocaryum spp., Bactris maraja, B. cf. monticola,
   Ceroxylon quindiuense, Elaeis oleifera, Iriartea deltoidea, Mauritia fl
   exuosa, M. carana, Oenocarpus bataua, O. mapora, O. multicaulis,
   Phytelephas macrocarpa, Phytelephas cf. tenuicaulis and Socratea
   salazarii, and also from Bactris gasipaes unknown in natural conditions.
   The palm tree Attalea funifera, also studied, is limited to the atlantic
   coast of Brazil.

   Sciences, St. Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.

   Priops mexicanus - Reitter 1873 (Nitidulidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   391].

PT J
AN ZOOR14712083985
DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision and phylogeny of the genus Aneorhachis Kleine 1923
   (Coleoptera: Brentidae: Microtrachelizini).
AU Mantilleri, Antoine (amantill@mnhn.fr) 
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 3-4
PS 439-448
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A taxonomic revision of the genus Aneorhachis Kleine 1923 (Coleoptera:
   Brentidae) and a phylogenetic analysis of species belonging to this
   genus are carried out. The genus Ipsopisthius Kabakov 2001 is
   synonymised with Aneorhachis, and two new combinations are proposed:
   Aneorhachis hirta (Kabakov 2001), n. comb. and A. incerta (Kleine 1935),
   n. comb. Higonius nitens Goossens 2008 is synonymized with A. incerta.
   One new species is described from New Guinea, A. papuana n. sp. All the
   species are redescribed and type-specimens are illustrated; an
   identification key is proposed. A maximum parsimony analysis is provided
   on the base of 23 characters from adult morphology. This analysis confi
   rms the monophyly of the genus and seems to show that Aneorhachis
   originated on continental Asia and then spread out eastward to colonize
   Pacific islands.
C1 Mantilleri, Antoine; Museum national d'Histoire naturelle, Entomologie,
   CP 50, 45 rue Buffon, F[long dash]75231 Paris Cedex 05, France, France.
EM amantill@mnhn.fr
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology
SN 0037-9271
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Australasia; Oceanic
   islands
DE Aneorhachis [Phylogeny /  / taxonomic revision] [Zoogeography /  / ]
   [Asia / South east / ] [Pacific Ocean islands /  / ]. 
   Aneorhachis papuana [Papua New Guinea /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Brentidae
OR Aneorhachis - Kleine 1923 (Brentidae): [Syn nov, Ipsopisthius Kabakov
   2001, p. 441; Key to species, P. 445]. 
   Aneorhachis astricta - Kleine 1923 (Brentidae): [Redescription, P. 441].
   
   Aneorhachis fijiana - Mantilleri 2009 (Brentidae): [Redescription, P.
   445]. 
   Aneorhachis hirta - (Kabakov 2001) (Brentidae): [Redescription, P. 444;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Ipsopisthius, p. 444]. 
   Aneorhachis incerta - (Kleine 1935) (Brentidae): [Redescription, P. 444;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Microtrachelizus, p. 444; Syn nov, Higonius
   nitens Goossens 2008, p. 444]. 
   Aneorhachis monticola - Damoiseau 1987 (Brentidae): [Redescription, P.
   443]. 
   Aneorhachis papuana (Brentidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 445]. 
   Ipsopisthius hirtus - Kabakov 2001 (Brentidae): [Referred to,
   Aneorhachis, p. 444].

TI A new genus of net-winged beetles from Neotropical Region (Coleoptera:
   Lycidae).

U1 0

AB The new genus Brasilycus is proposed within the tribe Calopterini.
   Following new species are described in the genus: Brasilycus capixabus
   n. sp., B. rondonensis n. sp., and B. bolivianus n. sp., all from South
   America. Illustrations of diagnostic characters and key to Brasilycus
   are given.

DT Article
TI On the Relationship between Zaprionus spinipilus Chassagnard & McEvey
   and Z. vittiger Coquillett, the Type Species of theGenus Zaprionus
   (Diptera: Drosophilidae).
AU Yassin, Amir (yassin@legs.cnrs-gif.fr) 
   Amabis, Jose Mariano
   da Lage, Jean-Luc
   Debiais-Thibaud, Melanie
   David, Jean R.
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 3-4
PS 471-476
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Zaprionus vittiger Coquillett is the type species of the genus Zaprionus
   Coquillett. However, the species is only known from five old museum
   specimens collected from South Africa and Malawi. It has often been
   confused with many other Zaprionus species, especially with Z.
   spinipilus Chassagnard & McEvey, a widespread species in Africa known
   from Madagascar, Malawi, Ethiopia and Cameroon. We have recently
   collected flies from the type localities of both species (South Africa
   and Madagascar, respectively). This has prompted us to test the
   taxonomic boundaries of these two nominal species using molecular (the
   mitochondrial COII and the nuclear Amyrel genes), chromosomal,
   morphological (internal and external genitalia), and reproductive
   isolation analyses. The results suggest Z. spinipilus to be a junior
   synonym to Z. vittiger.
C1 Yassin, Amir; Laboratoire Evolution, Genomes et Speciation (LEGS),
   Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (CNRS), av. de la Terrasse,
   F-91198 Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, France, France.
EM yassin@legs.cnrs-gif.fr
RI Yassin, Amir/N-7957-2018; Yassin, Amir/P-5915-2019
OI Yassin, Amir/0000-0002-2590-5434; Debiais-Thibaud,
   Melanie/0000-0002-1377-2515
SC Reproductive Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0037-9271
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Reproduction; Reproductive system;
   Genetics; Cytogenetics; Evolution; Speciation; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region
DE Zaprionus spinipilus; Zaprionus vittiger [Reproduction / Reproductive
   isolation / taxonomic implications] [Genitalia / Genitalia morphology /
   ] [Chromosomes /  / ] [Molecular genetics / COII & Amyrel gene sequences
   / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Evolutionary isolation /  / ] [Africa /  /
   distribution]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Drosophilidae
OR Zaprionus spinipilus - Chassagnard & McEvey 1992 (Drosophilidae). 
   Zaprionus vittiger - Coquillet 1902 (Drosophilidae): [Syn nov, Zaprionus
   spinipilus Chassagnard & McEvey 1992, p. 476]. 
DI 10.1080/00379271.2010.10697683
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14712083991
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Taxonomic review of the posticata-group of Fannia Robineau-Desvoidy
   (Diptera: Fanniidae), with the description of two new species from
   China.
AU Wang, Ming-Fu
   Zhang, Dong (ernest8445@163.com) 
   Cheng, Xiao-Lan
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 3-4
PS 481-485
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB One of the species-groups of the genus Fannia Robineau-Desvoidy 1830, is
   the posticatagroup of Chillcott (1961). A review of the F.
   posticata-group is expanded to include 21 species worldwide. Two species
   are described as new to science from China: Fannia dianensis n. sp. and
   Fannia punctifemoralis n. sp. Fannia dasytophacela Feng & Xue is
   assigned to this group. Fannia posticata (Meigen) is redescribed, and a
   key to the known species of the F. posticata-group is provided.

   Forestry University, Beijing 100083, China, China.

DT Article
TI Revision of the western Palaearctic Mesoleptus (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae).
AU Jussila, Reijo
   Saaksjarvi, Ilari E. (ilari.saaksjarvi@utu.fi) 
   Bordera, Santiago
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 3-4
PS 499-518
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The western Palaearctic species of the genus Mesoleptus Gravenhorst 1829
   are redescribed and keys are given for their identification. Also a key
   for the identification of the three stilpnine genera (Atractodes,
   Mesoleptus, and Stilpnus) is given and the biology of the genus is
   discussed shortly. The following species are described as new:
   Mesoleptus hispanicus n. sp., M. sawoniewiczi n. sp. and M. tunisiensis
   n. sp. The male of Mesoleptus tobiasi Jonaitis is described for the
   first time. New combinations is M. incessor (Haliday). New synonyms
   number 143 and 34 lectotypes are chosen.

   Turku, Finland, Finland.

PT J
AN ZOOR14712084000
DT Article
TI Taxonomy of the genus Hesperus Fauvel (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae:
   Philonthina) from China.
AU Li, Liang
   Zhou, Hong-Zhang (zhouhz@ioz.ac.cn) 
   Schillhammer, Harald
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 3-4
PS 519-536
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Seven new species of the genus Hesperus Fauvel 1874 from China are
   described and illustrated: H. beijingensis sp. n. from Beijing, Henan,
   Hubei, Anhui, Zhejiang, Fujian, Sichuan and Yunnan; H. hainanensis sp.
   n. from Hainan and Guangxi; H. emeishanus sp. n. and H. pulchellus sp.
   n. from Sichuan; H. coarcticollis sp. n. from Yunnan; H.
   gracilantennatus sp. n. from Tibet and H. elongatus sp. n. from Yunnan
   and Hainan. Hesperus amabilis (Kraatz 1859) from Sichuan and Yunnan, and
   H. susannekontrusae Schillhammer 2005 from Hainan are reported from
   China for the first time. In addition, H. amabilis is also reported from
   Afghanistan, Thailand and Laos for the first time. Hesperus feae Fauvel
   1895 is placed in synonym with H. amabilis (Kraatz 1859). Thus, a total
   of 12 species of the genus Hesperus are known from China; and the world
   fauna of the genus is now increased to 219 species. A key to the Chinese
   species of the genus Hesperus is provided and species geographical
   distributions are discussed.
C1 Zhou, Hong-Zhang; Key Laboratory of Zoological Systematics and
   Evolution, Institute of Zoology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 1 Beichen
   West Rd., Chaoyang District, 100101 Beijing, China, China.
EM zhouhz@ioz.ac.cn

DT Article
TI New data on Troglorites breuili Jeannel 1919 (Coleoptera: Carabidae:
   Pterostichini): a hypogean Iberian species with description of a new
   subspecies.
AU Ortuno, Vicente M. (vicente.ortuno@uah.es) 
   Fresneda, Javier
   Baz, Arturo
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 46
IS 3-4
PS 537-549
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new subspecies of Troglorites breuili Jeannel 1919 (T. breuili
   salgadoi ssp. n.) which was discovered at Cueva del Viento, Mendaro,
   Guipuzcoa (Spain), is described. It features a prominent macrocephaly, a
   strongly transverse pronotum and peculiar cephalic setation. A
   morphometric analysis is presented, along with a redescription of the
   nominotypical subspecies [long dash]female genitalia are described in
   detail [long dash] and characterization of T. breuili mendizabali
   Jeannel 1921. The description also includes a chorological update of the
   three subspecies mentioned above, an inventory of the fauna that lives
   with each of them, and points are made about their biology and
   biogeography.
C1 Ortuno, Vicente M.; Departamento de Zoologia y Antropologia Fisica,
   Facultad de Biologia, Universidad de Alcala, E-28871 Alcala de Henares,
   Madrid, Spain, Spain.
EM vicente.ortuno@uah.es
RI Ramos, Arturo Baz/A-6159-2009
OI Ramos, Arturo Baz/0000-0002-6750-2940
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0037-9271

   ].

   systematics] [Zoogeography / Biogeography / ] [Spain /  / ]. 
   Troglorites breuili salgadoi [Spain /  / New subspecies].

DT Article
TI Taxonomy of the genus Adebrotus Lugo-Ortiz & McCafferty (Ephemeroptera:
   Baetidae).
AU Salles, Frederico F. (ffsalles@gmail.com) 
SO Annales de Limnologie
VL 46
IS 3
PS 207-215
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The taxonomy of the enigmatic genus Adebrotus Lugo-Ortiz & McCafferty is
   reviewed in the present paper The type-species, A amazonicus Lugo-Ortiz
   & McCafferty, is redescribed based on nymphs from Northern Brazil.
   Adebrotus bigot, new species, is described based on nymphs from
   Southeastern Brazil, significantly extending the distributional range of
   the genus In the light of these new evidences, the generic concept of
   Adebrotus is improved
C1 Salles, Frederico F.; Univ Fed Espirito Santo, Dept Ciencias Saude Biol
   & Agr, Sao Mateus, ES, Brazil, Brazil.
EM ffsalles@gmail.com
RI Salles, Frederico/C-3439-2013
OI Salles, Frederico/0000-0001-8331-5929

SN 0003-4088

   Neotropical region; South America

AN ZOOR14609060577
DT Article
TI New data on the genus Imerites Rouchadze, 1933 (Ammonitida,
   Ancyloceratina) answer and precisions are brought to the work of Bert,
   Delanoy and Canut, 2009.
FT Nouvelles donnees sur le genre Imerites Rouchadze, 1933 (Ammonitida,
   Ancyloceratina); reponses et precisions apportees au travail de Bert,
   Delanoy et Canut, 2009.
AU Vermeulen, Jean (jeanvermeulen@dbmail.com) 
   Lepinay, Patrick
SO Annales de Paleontologie
VL 96
IS 1
PS 13-23
PD Jan 2010
PY 2010
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB This work is mainly an answer to the work of Bert, Delanoy and Canut, on
   the genus Imerites Rouchadze, and we add also some points to the
   knowledge of this genus. An answer is given for the implication of one
   of the authors (J.V.) of this present work, about the origin of the
   genus Imerites Rouchadze, and some significant bibliographic references,
   not named in the 2009 work, are specified and placed in their context.
   The characteristics of the ornamental stage "Pseudoshasticrioceras"
   mainly defined by an oval and compressed section of the whorls and by
   regular ventrolateral clavi, well marked, which frame the venter in a
   typical way (Bert et al., p. 181), don't allow to affirm the presence of
   this stage during the ontogeny of all species of the genus Imerites
   Rouchadze, contrary to what Bert, Delanoy and Canut (p. 30, 31) wrote.
   The type-species of the genus Imerites Rouchadze is made clear by the
   application of the rules of the I.C.Z.N. code. The article 23, with the
   paragraph 23.1 of the I.C.Z.N. code, imply the senior synonymy of
   Imerites cristatus (Orbigny) on Imerites giraudi (Kilian), even if the
   Kilian's species is still the type species of the genus lmerites
   Rouchadze. The taxinomical validity of the species Imerites cristatus
   (Orbigny) is confirmed. Its morphological variability is clarified by
   the distinction of four referential morphotypes, Cristatus, Giraudi,
   Favrei and Raricostatum. Consequently, the assumption of a
   shape-dimensional dimorphism into the populations of the genus lmerites
   Rouchadze is rejected, awaiting irrefutable proof. A new species,
   Imerites stephaniae sp. nov., is described. It was collected in the
   Gerhardtia sartousiana Zone, in the uppermost part of the Gerhardtia
   provincialis Subzone, and it is a probable ancestor of the cogeneric
   species of the Imerites giraudi Zone. [copyright]2010 Elsevier Masson
   SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Vermeulen, Jean; Grand Rue, Barreme, France, France.
EM jeanvermeulen@dbmail.com
SC Evolutionary Biology; Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0753-3969; 1778-3666
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Shell; Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Imerites cristatus [Morphological variation /  / Taxonomic
   implications]. 
   Imerites stephaniae [France /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Pseudoshasticrioceras [Shell morphology / Shell ornamentation /
   Taxonomic implications]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Cephalopoda, Ammonoidea, Lytoceratida
OR Pseudoshasticrioceras - Delanoy 1999 (Ammonoidea): [Fossil]. 
   Imerites - Rouchadze 1933 (Lytoceratida): [Type species, P. 17; Fossil].
   
   Imerites cristatus - (Orbigny 1842) (Lytoceratida): [Fossil]. 
   Imerites stephaniae (Lytoceratida): [Sp nov, France, Cretaceous, P. 18;
   Fossil]. 
DI 10.1016/j.annpal.2010.01.003
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14609060577
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14709070198
DT Article
TI New and little-known species of Carabidae from the Middle East and
   Southeast Asia (Coleoptera, Carabidae: Lebiini, Brachinini).
AU Kirschenhofer, E. (kirschenhofer.erich@aon.at) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 102
PS 25-64
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Carabaid beetles of the tribes Lebiini and Brachinini are studied and
   twenty-three species from the Middle East (Israel) and Southeast Asia
   are described: Afrotarus golanensis sp. n. (type locality: Israel),
   Brachychila sabahensis sp. n. (Malaysia: Sabah), Coptodera cechovskyi
   sp. n. (Malaysia: Perak), Coptodera johorensis sp. n. (Malaysia: Johor),
   Coptodera mersingensis sp. n. (Malaysia: Johor), Dolichoctis pahangensis
   sp. n. (Malaysia: Pahang), Trichocoptodera indica sp. n. (India),
   Mochtherus sulawesiensis sp. n. (Indonesia: Sulawesi), Lebia
   (Poecilothais) cucphuongensis sp. n. (Vietnam), Lebia (Poecilothais)
   tuongensis sp. n. (Vietnam), Lebia (Poecilothais) nepalensis sp. n.
   (Nepal), Pseudocalleida pahangensis sp. n. (Malaysia: Pahang),
   Serrimargo pahangensis sp. n. (Malaysia: Pahang), Serrimargo
   vietnamensis sp. n. (Vietnam), Sofota perakensis sp. n. (Malaysia:
   Perak), Taridius (Perseus) jendeki sp. n. (India), Taridius (Perseus)
   wrasei sp. n. (Malaysia: Sabah), Brachinus (Brachynidius) lombokensis
   sp. n. (Indonesia: Lombok), Pheropsophus (Stenaptinus) nepalensis sp. n.
   (Nepal), Pheropsophus (Stenaptinus) tamdaoensis sp. n. (Vietnam),
   Pheropsophus (Stenaptinus) akhaensis sp. n. (Thailand), Pheropsophus
   (Stenaptinus) guanxiensis sp. n. (China: Guangxi), Pheropsophus
   (Stenaptinus) yunnanensis sp. n. (China:Yunnan). Perseus KIRSCHENHOFER,
   2003 is placed as a subgenus of genus Taridius CHAUDOIR, 1875. Perseus
   pahangensis KIRSCHENHOFER, 2003 and P. sabahensis KIRSCHENHOFER, 2003
   are therefore transferred to Taridius. Cymindis vietnamensis
   KIRSCHENHOFER, 1996 is transferred to the genus Taridius. Allocota
   sumatrensis KIRSCHENHOFER, 1996 is transferred to the genus Physodera
   ESCHSCHOLTZ, 1829 as Physodera eschscholtzi sumatrensis KIRSCHENHOFER
   stat. n. and comb. n. Pheropsophus nigerrimus JEDLICKA, 1935 is
   transferred to the genus Brachinus WEBER. Pseudocalleida gen. n.
   (Lebiini) is described. The following synonymy is proposed: Orthogonius
   crassicrus CHAUDOIR, 1871 = Actenoncus punctatus TIAN et DEUVE, 2006,
   syn. n. Identification keys for the species of Taridius CHAUDOIR, 1875,
   for Brachychila, CHAUDOIR, 1869 species with four-spotted elytra and for
   the Pheropsophus (Stenaptinus) aptinoides species group are provided.
   With 51 figures.
C1 Kirschenhofer, E.; Otto Elsner Gasse 10-12, A-2380 Perchtoldsdorf,
   Austria, Austria.
EM kirschenhofer.erich@aon.at
SC Zoology
SN 0521-4726

   zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; India

   Zhuang, P. 58].

   56].

TI New species and new records of Palaearctic Trichoptera in the material
   of the Hungarian Natural History Museum.
AU Olah, J. (profolah@gmail.com) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 102
PS 65-117
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB 223 Trichoptera species were determined from the Palaearctic material of
   the Hungarian Natural History Museum collected in Iran, Pakistan,
   Kazahstan, and from several countries along the Mediterranean Sea.
   Fifteen new species are described: Wormaldia albanica sp. n. (Albania),
   Pseudoneureclipsis adiabenorum sp. n. (Iran), Pseudoneureclipsis parthus
   sp. n. (Iran), Tinodes andrasi sp. n. (Croatia), Tinodes urdhva sp. n.
   (Albania), Rhyacophila akutila sp. n. (Bulgaria), Rhyacophila liutika
   sp. n. (Macedonia), Rhyacophila masula sp. n. (Iran), Lepidostoma
   yuechiorum sp. n. (Kazakhstan), Drusus arbanios sp. n. (Albania), Drusus
   dacothracus sp. n. (Albania), Drusus illyricus sp. n. (Albania), Drusus
   muranyorum sp. n. (Greece), Drusus pelasgus sp. n. (Albania) and
   Notidobia nogradorum sp. n. (Albania) Three species are redrawn:
   Wormaldia subnigra MCLACHLAN, 1865 (from Albania), Rhyacophila
   brevifurcata KUMANSKI, 1986 (from Montenegro) and Allogamus auricollis
   (PICTET, 1834) (from Montenegro). With 76 figures.

PT J
AN ZOOR14709070200
DT Article
TI Notes on the high Andean cloud forest butterfly genus Jagiello and its
   relatives with description of a new species from Peru (Lepidoptera:
   Lycaenidae).
AU Balint, Zs. (balint@nhmus.hu) 
   Kertesz, K.
   Wojtusiak, J.
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 102
PS 119-142
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The generic names Jagiello BALINT et WOJTUSIAK, 2000 and Trochusinus
   JOHNSON, SALAZAR et VELEZ, 1997 are reinstated from the synonymy of
   Timaeta JOHNSON, KRUSE et KROENLEIN, 1997 on the basis of unique
   characters. The hitherto unknown female of Timaeta christina ROBBINS et
   BUSBY, 2008 is characterized and illustrated. A new species, Jagiello
   boyeropampa sp. n., is described from southern Peru. A key for
   identification of species of Timaeta and Jagiello is presented. The
   diagnostic characters of Jagiello, Timaeta and Trochusinus are
   discussed, the character states are tabulated, and a new concept is
   proposed for their recognition resulting in eight new nomenclatural
   combinations: Trochusinus aepea (HEWITSON, 1874) comb. n., T. cospata
   (ROBBINS et BUSBY, 2008) comb. n., T. gabriela (BUSBY et ROBBINS, 2008)
   comb. n., T. matthewi (BUSBY et ROBBINS, 2008) comb. n., T. pilosa
   (ROBBINS et BUSBY, 2008) comb. n., T. roberti (BUSBY et ROBBINS, 2008)
   comb. n., T. romero (ROBBINS et BUSBY, 2008) comb. n. and T. walteri
   (BUSBY et ROBBINS, 2008) comb. n. With 32 figures and one table.
C1 Balint, Zs.; Department of Zoology, Hungarian Natural History Museum,
   H-1088 Budapest, Baross u. 13, Hungary, Hungary.
EM balint@nhmus.hu

SN 0521-4726

   morphology; Appendages; Colour and luminescence; Colour; Ecology;
   Distribution within habitat; Abiotic factors; Physical factors; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America

TI Two new parapatric species of the genus Eretris Thieme from the Andes in
   western Ecuador (Lepidoptera, Nymphalidae: Satyrinae).
AU Pyrcz, T. W. (pyrcztomasz@hotmail.com) 
   Wojtusiak, J.
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 102
PS 143-153
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eretris suprarufescens sp. n. and E. microrufescens sp. n. are described
   from the western Andes in Ecuador. They are closely related to each
   other and to E. apuleja C. et R. FELDER, (1867), which occurs
   allopatrically on the eastern slopes of the Andes. The two species are
   distributed parapatrically in adjacent elevation zones. With 14 figures.
C1 Pyrcz, T. W.; Zoological Museum of the Jagiellonian University,
   Ingardena 6, 30-060 Krakow, Poland, Poland.
EM pyrcztomasz@hotmail.com

   species].

TI A new Cremifania species from Bulgaria (Diptera, Cremifaniidae), with a
   proposal for wing venation terms in higher Diptera.
AU Papp, L. (lpapp@nhmus.hu) 
SO Annales Historico-Naturales Musei Nationalis Hungarici
VL 102
PS 193-204
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cremifania bulgarica sp. n. is described from Bulgaria with a key for
   the known species of the genus. The species is the fourth representative
   of the family Cremifaniidae, a family new to Bulgaria. A proposal is
   made for wing venation terms (nomenclature of wing veins) in higher
   Diptera. With 11 figures.

   Animal Ecology Research Group of the Hungarian Academy of Sciences,
   H-1088 Budapest, Baross utca 13, Hungary, Hungary.

TI THE GENUS NESOLOTIS MIYATAKE, 1966 (COLEOPTERA: COCCINELLIDAE) FROM
   CHINA, WITH DESCRIPTIONS OF EIGHT NEW SPECIES.
AU Wang, Xing-Min
   Ren, Shun-Xiang (rensxcn@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Chen, Xiao-Sheng
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 1-13
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Species of the genus Nesolotis Miyatake (Coleoptera: Coccinellidae:
   Sticholotidinae) endemic to China are reviewed, and the genus is removed
   from synonymy of Sticholotis Crotch. The following eight species are
   described as new to science: N. magnipunctata Wang et Ren, sp. nov., N.
   gladliformis Wang et Ren, sp. nov., N. denticulata Wang et Ren, sp.
   nov., N. nigra Wang et Ren, sp. nov., N. centralis Wang et Ren, sp.
   nov., N. quadratimaculata Wang et Ren, sp. nov., N. cordiformis Wang,
   Ren et Chen, sp. nov. and N. daweishanensis Wang, Ren et Chen, sp. nov.
   A diagnosis of the genus and a key to known species from China are also
   provided.

   Guangzhou, Guangdong, China, China.

AB The Oriental genus Macroilleis Miyatake is revised. Three species are
   recognized, including one new species Macroilleis borneensis sp. nov.
   (Borneo, Sabah). All species are redescribed and illustrated. A key to

TI A NEW SPECIES AND NEW RECORDS OF THE GENUS NALASSUS MULSANT, 1854
   (COLEOPTERA: TENEBRIONIDAE: HELOPINI) FROM TURKEY.
AU Keskin, Bekir (bekir.keskin.phd@gmail.com) 
   Nabozhenko, Maxim V.
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 23-28
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A new species Nalassus bozdagus sp. nov. is described from the Aegean
   Region of Turkey (Bozdag ridge). The new species differs from all known
   Nalassus in the following characters: the hair spot on first and second
   abdominal sternites of male is absent, temple grooves are absent,
   exosceleton very strongly sclerotized. New records of Nalassus Mulsant,
   1854 from Turkey are provided. Two species new for the fauna of Turkey:
   Nalassus (Helopondrus) gloriosus (Faldermann, 1837) and N.
   (Helopocerodes) faldermanni (Faldermann, 1837).
C1 Keskin, Bekir; Ege Univ, Biol Sect, Bornova Izmir, Turkey, Turkey.
EM bekir.keskin.phd@gmail.com
RI Keskin, Bekir/A-3893-2016; Nabozhenko, Maxim/M-6109-2014
OI Keskin, Bekir/0000-0002-6662-8736; Nabozhenko, Maxim/0000-0001-7914-7942

DT Article
TI BRACHYPSECTRA KADLECI SP. NOV. FROM WESTERN IRAN - THE FIRST PALAEARCTIC
   MEMBER OF THE FAMILY BRACHYPSECTRIDAE (INSECTA: COLEOPTERA:
   ELATERIFORMIA).
AU Hajek, Jiri (jiri_hajek@nm.cz) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 29-33
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Brachypsectra kadleci sp. nov. from Zagros Mts., western Iran, a new
   species of the genus Brachypsectra LeConte, 1874, is described and
   illustrated. Based on the pectinate club formed by six antennomeres, the
   new species is closely related to both the previously known Oriental
   Brachypsectra, described by Blair (1930). Brachypsectra kadleci sp. nov.
   represents the first record of the family Brachypsectridae in the
   Palaearctic region.
C1 Hajek, Jiri; Natl Museum, Dept Entomol, Kunratice 1, Prague, Czech
   Republic, Czech Republic.

DT Article
TI REVISIONAL STUDY ON THE GENUS MIMASTRA (COLEOPTERA: CHRYSOMELIDAE:
   GALERUCINAE). PART 2.
AU Bezdek, Jan (bezdek@mendelu.cz) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 35-46
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of Mimastra Baly, 1865, are described, illustrated and
   compared with related taxa: M. strejceki sp. nov. (Indonesia: Java), M.
   andrewesi sp. nov. and M. nilgiriensis sp. nov. (both India: Tamil Nadu
   state). Haplosoma longicornis Allard, 1888 and Trichomimastra itoi
   Takizawa, 1986 are transferred to Mimastra (comb. nov.). For the reason
   of homonymy, a new name M. jacobyi nom. nov. is proposed for M.
   longicornis Jacoby, 1892 (nee M. longicornis (Allard, 1888)). The
   lectotypes are designated for M. arcuata Baly, 1865 and H. longicornis
   Allard, 1888. The drawings of both male and female genitalia are
   presented for all species. Mimastra arcuata is reported for the first
   time from Myanmar.
C1 Bezdek, Jan; Mendel Univ, Dept Zool, Zemedelska 1, Brno, Czech Republic,
   Czech Republic.
EM bezdek@mendelu.cz
RI Bezdek, Jan/J-3548-2018

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS CATAGLYPHIS FOERSTER, 1850 (HYMENOPTERA:
   FORMICIDAE) FROM IRAN.
AU Radchenko, Alexander (agradchenko@hotmail.com) 
   Paknia, Omid
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 69-76
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Two new species, Cataglyphis stigmatus sp. nov. and C. pubescens sp.
   nov. are described based on workers from Iran. The first species belongs
   to the bicolor species-group and clearly differs from all known species
   of this group by its yellow colour (except of C. lunaticus), but well
   distinguishes from the latter by the longer scape, by the lower
   propodeum, which dorsal surface is distinctly longer than the posterior
   one, by the less abundant standing hairs on the alitrunk and petiole,
   and especially by the much longer propodeal spiracles. Taxonomic
   position of C. pubescens is less clear, it shares features of the
   cursor-, enzeryi- and emmae-groups, while differs from all species of
   these groups by the dense and long depressed pubescence on the head and
   alitrunk.
C1 Radchenko, Alexander; Polish Acad Sci, Museum Zool, 64 Wilcza Str,
   Warsaw, Poland, Poland.
EM agradchenko@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cataglyphis pubescens; Cataglyphis stigmatus [Iran /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae
OR Cataglyphis pubescens (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 71]. 
   Cataglyphis stigmatus (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 70]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14607049649
DA 2020-09-17

AB A new subgenus, Pacificophanes subgen. nov., of the genus Caenophanes
   Foerster with two new species C. (P.) baloghi sp. nov. (type species)
   and C. (P.) neocaledonicus sp. nov. are described from the New

DT Article
TI LAASBIUM SCUDDER: A GENUS OF TERTIARY EARWIGS, NOT ROVE BEETLES, AND THE
   CLASSIFICATION OF FLORISSANT FOSSIL DERMAPTERA (INSECTA).
AU Chatzimanolis, Stylianos (stylianos-chatzimanolis@utc.edu) 
   Engel, Michael S.
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 101-108
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The Tertiary genus Laasbium Scudder, originally described with two
   species and as a lineage of staphylinid beetles (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae) from the Eocene-Oligocene boundary of Florissant,
   Colorado, is re-evaluated. Examination of the original series for
   Laasbium agassizii Scudder (type species) and Laasbium sectile Scudder
   reveal that these represent incompletely preserved earwigs (Dermaptera).
   The genus Laasbium is transferred to the order Dermaptera and comments
   provided on the classification of Florissant fossil earwigs, all
   previously placed in the genus Labiduromma Scudder. A lectotype is
   designated for Laasbium agassizii and the following six new genera
   erected to accommodate the diversity of Florissant fossil earwigs
   (authorship of all taxa is Engel and Chatzimanolis): Petrolabis (type
   species: Labiduromma gurneyi Brown), Litholabis (type species:
   Labiduromma gilberti Scudder), Rupiforficula (type species: Labiduromma
   scudderi Brown), Geroncolabis (type species: Labiduromma tertiaria
   Scudder), Spiladopygia (type species: Labiduromma exsultatum Scudder),
   and Paleocarcinophora (type species: Labiduromma lithophila Scudder).
   The following new combinations are established: Petrolabis gurneyi
   (Brown), Litholabis gilberti (Scudder), Rupiforficula scudderi (Brown).
   Rupiforficula labens (Scudder), Rupiforficula inferna (Scudder).
   "Laasbium" sectile, a poorly-preserved lateral compression, is
   considered genus incertae sedis.
C1 Chatzimanolis, Stylianos; Univ Tennessee, Dept Biol & Environm Sci, 615
   McCallie Ave, Chattanooga, TN, USA, USA.
EM stylianos-chatzimanolis@utc.edu

   Stylianos/0000-0001-9008-0611

TI THE GENUS NEOCHAULIODES VAN DER WEELE (MEGALOPTERA: CORYDALIDAE) FROM
   INDOCHINA, WITH DESCRIPTION OF THREE NEW SPECIES.
AU Liu, Xingyue (liu_xingyue@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Hayashi, Fumio
   Yang, Ding
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 109-124
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A faunistic review of the fishily genus Neochauliodes van der Weele from
   Indochina is given, with 11 species recorded. Amongst them, three
   species are described as new to science: Neochauliodes bachmanus sp.
   nov., Neochauliodes confusus sp. nov., and Neochauliodes tamdaoensis sp.
   nov. Neochauliodes orientalis Yang et Yang, 1992 and Neochauliodes
   yunnanensis Navas, 1930 are synonymized with Neochauliodes tonkinensis
   (van der Weele, 1907).

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF ANTENNOSEIUS FROM AUSTRALIA (ACARI: MESOSTIGMATA:
   ASCIDAE).
AU Gwiazdowicz, Dariusz J. (dagwiazd@up.poznan.pl) 
   Halliday, Bruce
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 125-132
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Antennoseius (Vitzthumia) ventrianalis sp. nov. is the second species of
   Antennoseius described from Australia (Acari: Ascidae). It is described
   from non-phoretic specimens collected from the soil surface. The new
   species is unique in having three pairs of ventral setae on the
   ventri-anal shield; the maximum observed in other species is two pairs.
   It is sexually dimorphic in the degree of fusion of the podonotal and
   opisthonotal shields and some other minor characters.
C1 Gwiazdowicz, Dariusz J.; Univ Life Sci, Dept Forest Protect, Ul Wojska
   Polskiego 71C, Poznan, Poland, Poland.
EM dagwiazd@up.poznan.pl

   Australasia; Australia

   species] [South Australia /  / ] [Western Australia /  / ].

DT Article
TI PROZERCON CELALI SP. NOV. OF SOIL MITES (ACARI: ZERCONIDAE) FROM TURKEY.
AU Urhan, Rasit (rurhan@pau.edu.tr) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 133-137
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB In this study, Prozercon celali sp. nov., collected from Honaz Mountain
   National Park in Turkey is described and illustrated on the basis of the
   adults females. Diagnostic characters of Prozercon celali:
   Postero-lateral tips of peritrematal shields reaching bases of marginal
   setae R3 or R4. Margin of opisthonotum with eight pairs of setae. Setae
   j1, r1, r4, r6, r7 markedly elongated, densely plumose, brush-like and
   apically rounded, setae j2, r2, r3 and r5 pilose or plumose, other
   podonotal setae short, smooth and neddle-like. Setae J1-J5, Z1-Z4 and S1
   plumose and apically tapering, seate J6, S2 and S4 densely plumose,
   brush-like and apically rounded. Setae S3 absent. Setae R1-R8 and Z5
   short and smooth. Dorsal cavities are distinct, sclerotized, equal in
   size and form. Additionally, a key to the adults of genus Prozercon
   known from Turkey is given.
C1 Urhan, Rasit; Pamukkale Univ, Fac Arts & Sci, POB 286 Kinikli, Denizli,
   Turkey, Turkey.
EM rurhan@pau.edu.tr
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   Prozercon celali [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Prozercon (Acari): [Key to species, Turkey, P. 136]. 
   Prozercon celali (Acari): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 133].

DT Article
TI ERIOPHYOID MITES (PROSTIGMATA: ERIOPHYOIDEA: ERIOPHYIDAE) FROM ICLEAND
   [ICELAND]: ONE NEW SPECIES, AND THREE NEW MITE RECORDS.
AU Szydlo, Wiktoria (wiktoria.szydlo@gmail.com) 
   Skaftason, Johannes Finnur
   Skoracka, Anna
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 1
PS 139-157
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB One new species of eriophyoid mite is described from Iceland and new
   records of three species from Iceland are presented. Aceria reykjaviki
   sp. nov., collected from Alpine Mouse-ear Chickweed Cerastium alpinum
   L., was described as new for science. Aceria thomasi (Nalepa), Aculops
   thymi (Nalepa), and Aculus tetanothrix (Nalepa) were recorded for the
   first time in Iceland. Aculops thymi was recorded for the first time as
   infesting Thymus praecox Opiz. As former descriptions are deficient,
   supplementary descriptions of females and males are provided for all
   three species. Nymphs are characterized for A. thomasi and A.
   tetanothrix.
C1 Szydlo, Wiktoria; Adam Mickiewicz Univ, Fac Biol, Umultowska 89, Poznan,
   Poland, Poland.

AB A new beetle species Notocupes pingi sp. nov. (Coleoptera: Cupedidae) is
   described from the well-known fossil site of Daohugou. With more than
   fifty species, Notocupes is the biggest Mesozoic genus of beetles but
   had not been previously found at this locality.

AB One new fossil genus and four new fossil species are described from the
   Late Tithonian-Berriasian Yixian Formation (Huangbanjigou) in China:
   Sinosperchopsis silinae gen. et sp. nov., Hydrophilopsia shatrovskiyi
   sp. nov., H. hydraenoides sp. nov. and H. gracilis sp. nov. (Coleoptera:
   Hydrophiloidea). The genus Sinosperchopsis is compared with all Mesozoic
   hydrophiloid genera known so far.

DT Article
TI PARANESEUTHIA FRANZ, 1986 OF AUSTRALO-ORIENTAL REGION, WITH NOTES ON
   PALEARCTIC SPECIES (COLEOPTERA: STAPHYLINIDAE: SCYDMAENINAE).
AU Jaloszynski, Pawel (scydmaenus@yahoo.com) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 2
PS 181-193
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of Paraneseuthia Franz are described: P. spinosa sp.
   nov. (Sumatra), P. bicolor sp. nov. (Sumatra), P. quadrifoveata, sp.
   nov. (Borneo, Sabah) and P. levigata sp. nov. (Papua New Guinea). An
   identification key to Australo-Oriental species of Paraneseuthia is
   given, and detailed morphology of the genus is described and illustrated
   on the basis of species from the northern and southern extremes of the
   known distributional range. Comparative analysis of morphology of E
   Palearctic and Australo-Oriental lineages of Paraneseuthia revealed only
   minor differences, restricted to the meso- and metaventrite and the
   aedeagus, and discussion of their systematic value is provided.
C1 Jaloszynski, Pawel; Os. Wichrowe Wzgorze 22/13, 61-678 Poznan, Poland,
   Poland.
EM scydmaenus@yahoo.com

   Evolution; Variation; Land zones; Australasian region; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Australasia

   [Morphological variation /  / ] [Australasian region /  / ] [ /  / Key
   to species] [Oriental region /  / ] [ /  / ] [Palaearctic region /  / ].

TI SULCIGNATHOS, A NEW SUBGENUS OF PACHYLISTER LEWIS, 1904 (COLEOPTERA:
   HISTERIDAE).
AU Mazur, Slawomir (slawomir.mazur@wl.sggw.pl) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 2
PS 209-214

PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new subgenus, Sulcignathos sub. nov., is erected to include
   Pachylister baconi, P. luctuosus and P. scaevola. The new following
   synonyms have been established: P. baconi (Marseul, 1854) = P.
   assamensis (Marseul, 1857) syn. nov., P. luctuosus (Marseul, 1854) = P.
   spinipes (Marseul, 1854) syn. nov., All the species of Sulcignathos are
   keyed and a general distribution is given for each of them. P. baconi is
   new to Nepal.

AB Orphinus (Orphinus) changdoi sp. nov. is described from Korean

   morphological details are added to the description of O. mroczkowskii
   Hava et Kadej, 2006 and the species is moved to the subgenus

AB The Greek species belonging to the genus Crypticus Latreille, 1817
   (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae: Diaperinae) are revised. Types of C.
   (Crypticus) thessalicus Reitter, 1896 are examined and a new species is
   described from the islands of Samos, Lesvos and Kos: C. (Platycrypticus)
   brusteli sp. nov. A key to species, photographs of habitus, geographical
   informations and a distribution map are bringing.

PT J

DT Article
TI TAXONOMIC NOTES ON THE GENUS GONOCEPHALUM SOLIER, 1834, WITH DESCRIPTION
   OF NEW TAXA (COLEOPTERA: TENEBRIONIDAE).
AU Ferrer, Julio (julio_ferrer@hotmail.com) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 2
PS 231-238
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The synantropic species Gonocephalum patruele (Erichson, 1843) is
   studied and separed from Gonocephalum sericeum (Baudi, 1875) previously
   confused with the West African species, introduced in Cabo Verde Islands
   and Transvaal, and separated in base of male and female genitaliae,
   pubescence of body and other characters. Both species belongs to a group
   of synantropic species, including Gonocephalum rusticum (Olivier, 1811).
   Gonocephalum patruele is studied and Gonocephalum sericeum (Baudi, 1875)
   stat. rest. previously confused with this species is redescribed from
   Egypt and from Almeria, Spain, introduced from Northern Africa.
   Gonocephalum sericeum, described from "Persia mer." is a species widely
   distributed in Northern Africa, from Morocco to Egypt, Israel and the
   Arabian Peninsula. The localities of origin and the geographic dispersal
   of this species are discussed. A new species, from Central Mongolia
   previously confused with Gonocephalum patruele ssp turchestanicum
   Gridelli, 1948, is described: Gonocephalum soederbomi sp. nov. and
   separated from Gonocephalum patruele ssp. turchestanicum Gridelli, 1948
   from Iran and from Turkestan. Gonocephalum puberulum Kaszab, 1952 is
   treated as a new homonymy of Gonocephalum puberulum Fauvel, 1867 nom.
   preocc. The name Gonocephalum javae nomen nov. is hereby proposed. Other
   taxa are described : Gonocephalum labriquei sp. nov. from China and G.
   dentitibia iwani ssp. nov. from North Rhodesia.
C1 Ferrer, Julio; Department of Entomology, The Swedish Museum ofNatural
   History, S-10405 Stockholm, Sweden, Sweden.
EM julio_ferrer@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Available name;
   Taxonomy; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Palaearctic region; Africa;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Gonocephalum dentitibia iwani [Zambia /  / New subspecies]. 
   Gonocephalum labriquei [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
   Gonocephalum soederbomi [Mongolia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Gonocephalum - Solier 1834 (Tenebrionidae): [Systematics, P. 231]. 
   Gonocephalum dentitibia iwani (Tenebrionidae): [Subsp nov, Zambia, P.
   236]. 
   Gonocephalum javae (Tenebrionidae): [Nom nov, For Gonocephalum puberulum
   Kaszab 1952, p. 236]. 
   Gonocephalum labriquei (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 234]. 
   Gonocephalum puberulum - Kaszab 1952 (Tenebrionidae): [Preoccupied name
   replaced by, Gonocephalum javae, p. 236]. 
   Gonocephalum sericeum - (Baudi 1875) (Tenebrionidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 234; Status, P. 234, Cited by author as Stat. rest.]. 
   Gonocephalum soederbomi (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Mongolia, P. 232].

DT Article
TI CATALOGUE OF THE WORLD GONOCEPHALUM SOLIER, 1834 (COLEOPTERA,
   TENEBRIONIDAE, OPATRINI). PART 1. LIST OF THE SPECIES AND SUBSPECIES.
AU Iwan, Dariusz (darek@robal.miiz.waw.pl) 
   Ferrer, Julio
   Ras, Marcin
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 2
PS 245-304
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The catalogue of all known World species of the genus Gonocephalum
   Solier, 1834 is presented: 3 subgenera, 415 species and subspecies are
   listed. The data of primary types and distribution for known species and
   subspecies are included. Gonocephalum zoltani nom. nov. is proposed as
   replacement name for Gonocephalum parallelum Kaszab, 1952 (nec
   Gonocephalum setulosum var. parallelum Normand, 1936) which is junior
   homonym; Gonocephalum neoblairi nom. nov. is proposed as replacement
   name for Gonocephalum Blain Kaszab, 1952 (nee Opatrum blairi Gebien,
   1922, presently placed in Gonocephalum) which is junior homonym. The
   following new homonyms are presented for the species presently placed in
   Gonocephalum: Hopatrum arenarium Fairmaire, 1894 nom. preoccup., nec
   Opatrum arenarium Fabricius, 1775; Gonocephalum curvicolle Gridelli,
   1934 nom. preoccup., nee Gonocephalum curvicolle Reitter, 1889;
   Gonocephalum pubens Gebien, 1913 nom. preoccup., nec Opatrum pubens
   Marseul, 1876; Opatrum pusillum Kuster, 1849 nom. preoccup., nee Opatrum
   pusillum Fabricius, 1791; Opatrum viennense Kuster, 1849 nom. preoccup.,
   nee Gonocephalum viennense Duftschmid, 1812; Opatrum modestum Kuster,
   1849 name preoccup. nee Opatrum modestum Reiche, 1847; Opatrum patruele
   Kuster, 1849 nom. preoccup. nec Opatrum patruele Erichson, 1843; Opatrum
   setulosum Kuster, 1849 nom. preoccup., nee Opatrum setulosum Faldermann,
   1837. Incertae sedis taxa are listed separately.

TI NEW AND LITTLE KNOWN SPECIES OF THE TRIBE MEGAPENTHINI GURJEVA, 1973
   (COLEOPTERA: ELATERIDAE) FROM SULAWESI.
AU Schimmel, Rainer (rainer.schimmel@gmx.de) 
   Tarnawski, Dariusz
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 3
PS 325-336
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Eight new species of the tribe Megapenthini from the Indonesian island
   Sulawesi are described and illustrated: Abelater bosi sp. nov., A.
   buechei sp. nov., A. dongalaensis sp. nov., A. jakubi sp. nov., Cateanus
   sulawesiensis sp. nov., Friedrichiellus bosi sp. nov., Simodactylus
   saetosus sp. nov., and Xanthopenthes dongalaensis sp. nov. New records
   of further eight species of the tribe Megapenthini from Sulawesi are
   given. Abelater brandti Schimmel, 2004, and A. jaechi Schimmel, 2004 are
   recorded from this island for the first time.

DT Article
TI REVISION OF THE GENUS CALVARIUM PIC, 1918 (COLEOPTERA: SCIRTIDAE). PART
   1. REDESCRIPTION OF THE GENUS AND CATALOGUE OF DESCRIBED TAXA.
AU Ruta, Rafal (scirtes@biol.uni.wroc.pl) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 3
PS 341-350
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Calvarium Pic is redescribed and morphological characters
   discussed. A catalogue of the world species is presented and several new
   combinations are proposed. Indiocyphon Pic is regarded as a junior
   synonym of Calvarium Pic. Calvarium maxi Pic is designated the type
   species of Calvarium Pic. Calvarium inimpressum Pic, 1955 and Calvarium
   semiobscurum concoloripenne Pic, 1953 are junior synonyms of Calvarium
   latithorax (Pic, 1950). Several species are transferred from Cyphon to
   Calvarium: Calvarium carolinense (Blair) comb. nov., C. cautum
   (Klausnitzer) comb. nov., C. dentation (Klausnitzer) comb. nov., C.
   foncki (Pic) comb. nov., C. fouqueti (Pic) comb. nov., C. gredleri
   (Klausnitzer) comb. nov., C. hashimotorum (Yoshitomi) comb. nov., C.
   johorense (Yoshitomi et Sato) comb. nov., C. latithorax (Pic) comb.
   nov., C. longior (Yoshitomi et Sato) comb. nov., C. notabile (Yoshitomi
   et Sato) comb. nov., C. paui (Pic) comb. nov., C. primitum (Klausnitzer)
   comb. nov., C. rotundatum (Klausnitzer) comb. nov., C. rufopacum
   (Klausnitzer) comb. nov., C. samuelsoni (Yoshitomi et Sato) comb. nov.,
   C. sulawesicum (Yoshitomi et Sato) comb. nov., C. takahashii (Yoshitomi
   et Sato) comb. nov. Two species are transferred from Calvarium to
   Cyphon: Cyphon massarti (Pic) comb. nov. and C. semiobscurum (Pic) comb.
   nov.
C1 Ruta, Rafal; Univ Wroclaw, Inst Zool, Przybyszewskiego 63-77, Wroclaw,
   Poland, Poland.

   348]. 
   Cyphon longior - Yoshimpto & Sato 2004 (Scirtidae): [Referred to,
   Calvarium, p. 348]. 
   Cyphon massarti - (Pic 1952) (Scirtidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Calvarium, p. 349]. 
   Cyphon notabilis - Yoshitomi & Sato 2004 (Scirtidae): [Referred to,
   Calvarium, p. 348]. 
   Cyphon paui - Pic 1918 (Scirtidae): [Referred to, Calvarium, p. 348]. 
   Cyphon primitus - Klausnitzer 1976 (Scirtidae): [Referred to, Calvarium,
   p. 348].

DT Article
TI TWO NEW SPECIES OF ORIBATID MITES (ACARI: ORIBATIDA) FROM ETHIOPIA.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Sidorchuk, Ekaterina A.
   Rybalov, Leonid B.
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 3
PS 407-417
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We described Machadobelba shtanchaevae sp. nov. and Microtegeus
   khaustovi sp. nov., collected in Bale Mountains National Park (Africa,
   Ethiopia). The first new species is similar to Machadobelba symmetrica
   Balogh, 1958 (Distribution: Africa, Congo) and to Machadobelba ceylonica
   Balogh, 1970 (Asia, Sri Lanka), but differs from the former species by
   body size, length of costulae and length of notogastral setae, and from
   the latter species by body size, morphology of cristae and position of
   adanal setae ad3. Microtegeus khaustovi sp. nov. is similar to
   Microtegeus variabilis Mahunka, 1988 (Africa, Tanzania) and Microtegeus
   rugosus Mahunka, 1982 (Africa, Ethiopia), but differs from the former
   species by body size, number of prodorsal tubercles, length of
   notogastral setae c, and morphology of the notogaster; from the latter
   species it differs by morphology of lamellar setae, the number of
   prodorsal tubercles, and morphology of the notogaster.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Ctr Independent Examinat NN, Entomol Lab, Gagarin
   97, Nizhniy Novgorod, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
RI Sidorchuk, Ekaterina/G-3089-2014
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Machadobelba shtanchaevae; Microtegeus khaustovi [Ethiopia /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Machadobelba ceylonica (Acari): [Diagnostic characters, P. 409]. 
   Machadobelba shtanchaevae (Acari): [Sp nov, Ethiopia, P. 408]. 
   Machadobelba symmetrica (Acari): [Diagnostic characters, P. 409]. 
   Microtegeus khaustovi (Acari): [Sp nov, Ethiopia, P. 409]. 
   Microtegeus rugosus (Acari): [Diagnostic characters, P. 411]. 
   Microtegeus variabilis (Acari): [Diagnostic characters, P. 411].

TI REVISION OF THE OMASPIDES AUGUSTA GROUP (COLEOPTERA: CHRYSOMELIDAE:
   CASSIDINAE: MESOMPHALIINI).
AU Borowiec, Lech (cassidae@biol.uni.wroc.pl) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 4
PS 481-492
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Omaspides augusta group is revised. Omaspides augusta Boheman, 1856, O.
   bivittata Baly, 1872, and O. tenuicula Boheman, 1862 are redescribed.
   Two species are described as new: O. confusa sp. nov. (Ecuador) and O.
   picaflorensis sp. nov. (Peru). Two genera of Convolvulaceae plants,
   Merremia Dennst. ex Endl. and Turbina Raf., are recorded as hosts for
   the genus Omaspides Chevrolat, 1836 for the first time.
C1 Borowiec, Lech; Univ Wroclaw, Inst Zool, Przybyszewskiego 63-77,
   PL-51148 Wroclaw, Poland, Poland.

   Omaspides confusa [Food plants /  / New record] [Ecuador /  / New
   species].

   species].

DT Article
TI REVISION OF THE AUSTRALIAN COCCINELLIDAE (COLEOPTERA). GENUS DIOMUS
   MULSANT. PART 2.
AU Pang, Hong (Lsshpang@mail.sysu.edu.cn) 
   Slipinski, Adam
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 60
IS 4
PS 493-545
PD 2010
PY 2010
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB This paper is the second in a series designed to cover taxonomically all
   Australian species of Diomus Mulsant. Nomenclatural history, diagnoses,
   digital illustrations and distribution maps are provided for each
   species. Thirty species are treated in this paper, among those 14 are
   new: D. bunya sp. nov., D. carbine sp. nov., D. circus sp. nov., D.
   gingera sp. nov., D. gilvus sp. nov., D. hebes sp. nov., D. kioloa sp.
   nov., D. leai sp. nov., D. lord sp. nov., D. micrus sp. nov., D. pisinus
   sp. nov., D. prodigialis sp. nov., D. tasmanicus sp. nov. and D. vial's
   sp. nov. Diomus hypocrtus Weise, 1923 is synonymised with Scymnus
   mareebensis Blackburn, 1895 syn. nov. Lectotypes are designated for the
   following taxa to stabilize their taxonomic positions: Diomus hypocrtus
   Weise, 1923; scymnus cowleyi Blackburn, 1895; S. elutus Lea, 1902; S.
   flavifrons var. norfolcensis Lea, 1929; S. frater Lea, 1902; S. impictus
   Blackburn, 1895; S. inaffectatus Blackburn, 1892; S. insidiosus
   Blackburn, 1889; S. macrops Lea, 1929; S. maestus Lea, 1926; S.
   mareebensis Blackburn, 1895; S. obumbradus Blackburn, 1895; S. sublatus
   Blackburn, 1892; S. triangularis Lea, 1902; S. whittonensis Blackburn,
   1892; S. victoriensis Blackburn, 1892 and S. yarrensis Blackburn, 1895.

   China, China.

TI FIVE NEW SPECIES OF THE SUBGENUS OXYPHORTICA FROM THE ORIENTAL REGION

VL 60

LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Five new species discovered from the Oriental region: Stegana
   (Oxyphortica) crassiforcipata sp. nov., S (O.) curvata sp. nov., S. (O.)
   monoacantha sp. nov., S. (O.) wanglei sp. nov. and S. (O.) wuliangi sp.
   nov. are described. All are morphologically similar to S. (O.)
   subconvergens Okada, 1988 from Sri Lanka and S. (O.) enigma Sidorenko,
   1998 from Vietnam. A key to the species that similar to S. (O.)
   subconvergens is provided.
